description:
John Spence is recognized as one of the Top 100 Business Thought Leaders in America, one of the Top 100 Small Business Influencers in America, and one of the Top 500 Leadership Development Experts in the World. 
In these nine videos, John covers the essential skills necessary to build a highly successful career. Topics include communications, leadership, team building, conflict resolution, negations and other helpful business and career lessons.
name: Professional Development
subtitle: Professional Development

episodes.description: One of the most critical areas for career success, this section covers advanced questioning, the five levels of listening, body language, social styles and several more communication skills.
episodes.title: Advanced Communications
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.004 --> 00:00:05.474
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.474 --> 00:00:07.000
Hello and welcome to BizProTV.

3
00:00:07.000 --> 00:00:08.870
I'm your host Peter Van Rysdam.

4
00:00:08.870 --> 00:00:12.860
In today's episode we're gonna be talking
about professional development and

5
00:00:12.860 --> 00:00:15.490
specifically advanced communications.

6
00:00:15.490 --> 00:00:19.600
And here to help us with that we
have John Spence who is an author,

7
00:00:19.600 --> 00:00:24.100
a speaker, a businessman, an entrepreneur.

8
00:00:24.100 --> 00:00:25.772
John, tell us a little bit about yourself.

9
00:00:25.772 --> 00:00:29.900
>> I began my early career at
the Rockefeller Foundation.

10
00:00:29.900 --> 00:00:34.800
At age 26, I was named CEO of that
foundation overseeing projects in

11
00:00:34.800 --> 00:00:36.660
about 20 countries around the world.

12
00:00:36.660 --> 00:00:39.800
Since then, I've been the owner or
CEO of five other firms, three of them

13
00:00:39.800 --> 00:00:44.910
international, written about seven books
and for the last 20 years, I've traveled

14
00:00:44.910 --> 00:00:49.340
all over the world to help businesses and
people improve and be more successful.

15
00:00:49.340 --> 00:00:52.270
>> Great, well, I think a great
place to start that journey

16
00:00:52.270 --> 00:00:55.080
in professional development is
with advanced communications and

17
00:00:55.080 --> 00:00:56.190
what we're talking about today.

18
00:00:56.190 --> 00:01:00.300
And so when I think about communications,
I think about talking, and

19
00:01:00.300 --> 00:01:01.870
asking questions and then listening.

20
00:01:01.870 --> 00:01:03.380
So where do you wanna start today?

21
00:01:03.380 --> 00:01:06.070
>> Well, you put it in the order
that most people think about it,

22
00:01:06.070 --> 00:01:07.820
which is talking first.

23
00:01:07.820 --> 00:01:11.290
But in a lot of the research I've done,
looking at people that

24
00:01:11.290 --> 00:01:15.440
really admire communicators,
it's actually asking questions and

25
00:01:15.440 --> 00:01:17.850
listening are the two
most important skills.

26
00:01:17.850 --> 00:01:20.880
So, we're gonna start with some
advanced questioning skills.

27
00:01:20.880 --> 00:01:22.620
And here is the big idea with this,

28
00:01:22.620 --> 00:01:26.950
is the quality of your questions
determine the quality of your answers.

29
00:01:26.950 --> 00:01:30.610
And if your really trying to get good
solid information from the person

30
00:01:30.610 --> 00:01:35.380
you are talking too, it's essential
that you take the time to ask really

31
00:01:35.380 --> 00:01:39.030
pointed questions that is gonna get you
the answers and the information you need.

32
00:01:39.030 --> 00:01:42.470
And there is a couple of tricks to that,
a couple of tools.

33
00:01:42.470 --> 00:01:45.530
And the first tool I like
is one called cushions.

34
00:01:45.530 --> 00:01:48.940
And what a cushion does is it says
because I read some information,

35
00:01:48.940 --> 00:01:53.690
because I saw something, I now need
to ask you this detailed question.

36
00:01:53.690 --> 00:01:57.840
So it sounds something like I was
looking over the email you sent me and

37
00:01:57.840 --> 00:02:00.070
reading about the problems
you're expressing and

38
00:02:00.070 --> 00:02:03.830
I was wondering if you can take about two
or three minutes and help me understand,

39
00:02:03.830 --> 00:02:07.950
in as much detail as possible,
exactly where you think you need help.

40
00:02:07.950 --> 00:02:10.550
So what I've done there, is I've said,
I'm not just gonna bullet point you,

41
00:02:10.550 --> 00:02:12.105
You know,
I need you to tell me what's going on.

42
00:02:12.105 --> 00:02:14.190
So I'm gonna ease into that question.

43
00:02:14.190 --> 00:02:17.300
See there's a reason I'm asking
this sort of a question.

44
00:02:17.300 --> 00:02:19.020
So that's a cushion.

45
00:02:19.020 --> 00:02:23.950
The condition also does something like
that which says I've studied this,

46
00:02:23.950 --> 00:02:28.850
I've talked to someone on my team, there's
some new data that just came out, or

47
00:02:28.850 --> 00:02:31.080
a new version of the software,
whatever whatever it might be.

48
00:02:31.080 --> 00:02:35.950
And because of this new condition, I've
now got to ask you some more information.

49
00:02:35.950 --> 00:02:36.560
So that one, again,

50
00:02:36.560 --> 00:02:41.320
would sound like I understand that there's
been some issues in your department.

51
00:02:41.320 --> 00:02:44.745
It's probably because we
installed a different version.

52
00:02:44.745 --> 00:02:48.065
Because of that can I take a minute and
get you to give me some feedback on this.

53
00:02:48.065 --> 00:02:49.695
So the cushioning is in.

54
00:02:49.695 --> 00:02:54.045
The condition always uses the piece of
information as the driver of the question.

55
00:02:54.045 --> 00:02:56.855
The next thing I like are scale questions.

56
00:02:56.855 --> 00:03:01.816
And these are real easy, I use them a ton
myself which is on a scale of one to ten,

57
00:03:01.816 --> 00:03:03.770
how challenging is this issue?

58
00:03:03.770 --> 00:03:05.780
How bad is the problem?

59
00:03:05.780 --> 00:03:08.280
And if someone says a nine, you go,
okay I've got an emergency here.

60
00:03:08.280 --> 00:03:09.430
I've got to work on it.

61
00:03:09.430 --> 00:03:11.950
If they go a three you go, great.

62
00:03:11.950 --> 00:03:12.700
Well, let's get to it.

63
00:03:12.700 --> 00:03:15.630
We can put it in the queue or
wherever it might be.

64
00:03:15.630 --> 00:03:19.240
The other way I like to use
these is comfort level.

65
00:03:19.240 --> 00:03:23.940
So I bring someone something new to
look at, some new system to work on.

66
00:03:23.940 --> 00:03:25.200
And they've never seen it before.

67
00:03:25.200 --> 00:03:26.748
And I say on a scale of one to ten,

68
00:03:26.748 --> 00:03:30.900
with ten being I'm super comfortable,
I understand this, got it, no problem,

69
00:03:30.900 --> 00:03:34.935
and one being, I don't understand
this at all, where are you right now?

70
00:03:34.935 --> 00:03:38.210
[LAUGH] And again,
if they say three, you go uh-oh.

71
00:03:38.210 --> 00:03:42.260
What will it take to get you to a five,
or to a seven, or to a nine?

72
00:03:42.260 --> 00:03:46.500
So those scale questions are a good way
to make it easy for someone to tell you

73
00:03:46.500 --> 00:03:51.740
how they feel, their level of concern,
how well they're understanding things.

74
00:03:51.740 --> 00:03:54.390
The next one is a real fun one and
probably going to work great for

75
00:03:54.390 --> 00:03:59.330
IT people, is what I call expansion or
contraction questions.

76
00:03:59.330 --> 00:04:03.460
An expansion question is when you've got
someone that you ask them a question and

77
00:04:03.460 --> 00:04:04.678
they just answer it with yes or no.

78
00:04:04.678 --> 00:04:09.179
[SOUND] Yeah,
this is not helping me at all.

79
00:04:09.179 --> 00:04:13.871
So an expansion question says could you
take two or three minutes and share with

80
00:04:13.871 --> 00:04:19.190
me everything you're concerned about so
I can really understand your problem?

81
00:04:19.190 --> 00:04:23.420
So I'm forcing through the question to get
the person to give me more information,

82
00:04:23.420 --> 00:04:26.480
more data,
not just answer it with a yes or a no.

83
00:04:26.480 --> 00:04:30.470
The reverse of that id when you get
someone that you ask them a question and

84
00:04:30.470 --> 00:04:32.940
they go on 15 minutes and
tell you everything that's ever happened.

85
00:04:32.940 --> 00:04:36.170
First time they saw a computer,
first time they ever had a laptop.

86
00:04:36.170 --> 00:04:38.170
And all this information you don't need.

87
00:04:38.170 --> 00:04:42.760
On a contraction question, you go could
you just take one minute or less and

88
00:04:42.760 --> 00:04:45.490
share with me the single
most important thing

89
00:04:45.490 --> 00:04:47.860
you think I need to know
about this situation?

90
00:04:47.860 --> 00:04:51.200
So one says, talk a long the time, the
other one says basically just shut up and

91
00:04:51.200 --> 00:04:52.870
tell me what I need to know.

92
00:04:52.870 --> 00:04:56.670
And then the last one is what
I all relationship questions.

93
00:04:56.670 --> 00:04:59.310
And what relationship
questions are all about.

94
00:04:59.310 --> 00:05:00.849
Does this feel comfortable to you?

95
00:05:00.849 --> 00:05:03.010
Does it seem like I'm on track with you?

96
00:05:03.010 --> 00:05:05.203
Do you feel like everything is going okay?

97
00:05:05.203 --> 00:05:08.500
So I've hit the logical
questions of asking for data.

98
00:05:08.500 --> 00:05:13.720
Now I'm asking relationship or emotional
questions to see do they feel okay?

99
00:05:13.720 --> 00:05:15.330
Am I going at a good pace?

100
00:05:15.330 --> 00:05:17.450
Am I teaching them things they need to do?

101
00:05:17.450 --> 00:05:20.190
Am I solving the problems that they have?

102
00:05:20.190 --> 00:05:23.022
So that they feel good about
how I'm interacting with them.

103
00:05:23.022 --> 00:05:24.650
>> All right John,
I never actually realized there were

104
00:05:24.650 --> 00:05:27.860
that many different types of questions but
I guess it doesn't matter

105
00:05:27.860 --> 00:05:30.830
what kind of questions you ask if you
don't take time to listen to the answers.

106
00:05:30.830 --> 00:05:35.130
So what are some tips there to
help us kind of listen better?

107
00:05:35.130 --> 00:05:36.790
>> Yes, you put it real well Peter.

108
00:05:36.790 --> 00:05:39.510
Step one is you've got to be insanely
curious and ask great questions.

109
00:05:39.510 --> 00:05:42.830
And in the words I like to use,
you've got to be an intense listener.

110
00:05:42.830 --> 00:05:45.290
And there's five levels of listening.

111
00:05:45.290 --> 00:05:46.430
So let's go through those.

112
00:05:46.430 --> 00:05:48.120
Level one is not listening.

113
00:05:48.120 --> 00:05:49.628
Not paying attention at all.

114
00:05:49.628 --> 00:05:52.600
Not, looking down at your cell phone,
not looking up at all and

115
00:05:52.600 --> 00:05:54.375
being completely out of the conversation.

116
00:05:54.375 --> 00:05:58.720
Level two is distracted listening and
in distracted listening,

117
00:05:58.720 --> 00:06:02.130
now you're looking at your monitor, you're
checking your texts, you're doing things.

118
00:06:02.130 --> 00:06:04.450
And you're kind of nodding and
looking up every now and then.

119
00:06:04.450 --> 00:06:07.300
But they can tell you're not
really in the conversation.

120
00:06:07.300 --> 00:06:10.270
Level three is listening to answer.

121
00:06:10.270 --> 00:06:11.980
And this is what a lot of people do.

122
00:06:11.980 --> 00:06:14.490
I hear you talking, but
the whole time you're talking,

123
00:06:14.490 --> 00:06:17.440
I'm thinking about how am I gonna
answer this, how can I fix the problem,

124
00:06:17.440 --> 00:06:20.450
what am I gonna say next,
what do I say to look good.

125
00:06:20.450 --> 00:06:22.420
So you're only partially listening and

126
00:06:22.420 --> 00:06:27.760
mostly thinking in your head about what
you wanna say when they finally shut up.

127
00:06:27.760 --> 00:06:30.800
The next level is attentive listening.

128
00:06:30.800 --> 00:06:33.160
And in attentive listening,
you're doing the things you need to.

129
00:06:33.160 --> 00:06:34.930
You've got good body language.

130
00:06:34.930 --> 00:06:35.890
You're paying attention.

131
00:06:35.890 --> 00:06:37.340
You're using head nods.

132
00:06:37.340 --> 00:06:38.830
You're catching their information.

133
00:06:38.830 --> 00:06:40.120
You're paraphrasing and

134
00:06:40.120 --> 00:06:44.260
summarizing which are two really
important tools in listening.

135
00:06:44.260 --> 00:06:46.460
Paraphrasing, well let me go backwards.

136
00:06:46.460 --> 00:06:49.750
Summarizing says,
I listened to you and I heard you.

137
00:06:49.750 --> 00:06:53.550
You just said, a, b, c,
and d, is that correct?

138
00:06:53.550 --> 00:06:56.280
I can summarize the information
you gave me exactly.

139
00:06:56.280 --> 00:06:58.580
And that shows you're listening,
that's really great.

140
00:06:58.580 --> 00:07:03.180
Paraphrasing on the other hand says,
I listened to you carefully enough that I

141
00:07:03.180 --> 00:07:06.958
can reword what you just said,reword and
say it in my own words.

142
00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:10.644
In other words,you just said a,b,c and
d but

143
00:07:10.644 --> 00:07:14.730
to me it sounds like
what you mean is x,y,z.

144
00:07:14.730 --> 00:07:16.010
Is that correct?

145
00:07:16.010 --> 00:07:18.400
And if the other person looks at you and
says yes.

146
00:07:18.400 --> 00:07:22.090
What they've realized is this
person listened so well that they

147
00:07:22.090 --> 00:07:26.333
understood what I said and gave it back to
me in a different way that I agree with.

148
00:07:26.333 --> 00:07:27.770
So that's attentive listening.

149
00:07:27.770 --> 00:07:31.050
It's got the body language,
summarizing, paraphrasing.

150
00:07:31.050 --> 00:07:33.540
The highest level is intense listening.

151
00:07:33.540 --> 00:07:36.720
And at this level you're actually
hearing things that aren't being said.

152
00:07:36.720 --> 00:07:39.410
And a lot of this is around empathy,
and emotion, and

153
00:07:39.410 --> 00:07:43.390
looking for people who are upset,
or frustrated, or

154
00:07:43.390 --> 00:07:48.270
confused, and being able to see from their
body language that even though you're

155
00:07:48.270 --> 00:07:52.280
listening in they're talking, that you're
not really making an emotional connection.

156
00:07:52.280 --> 00:07:54.700
And that last level
doesn't happen very often,

157
00:07:54.700 --> 00:07:59.010
that's usually only between very very
close friends, spouses, things like that.

158
00:07:59.010 --> 00:08:03.106
Only about 30 % of people reach
even the active listening level.

159
00:08:03.106 --> 00:08:07.720
So one of the biggest problems
in almost all organizations is

160
00:08:07.720 --> 00:08:12.670
poor communications and one of the number
one limiting factors in people's careers

161
00:08:12.670 --> 00:08:17.370
is not being able to communicate
efficiently and listen intensely.

162
00:08:17.370 --> 00:08:20.980
>> John I think on that one I was the
third one I was listening to the answer

163
00:08:20.980 --> 00:08:23.640
because I was kind of getting ready for
my next questions here.

164
00:08:23.640 --> 00:08:26.840
But once I learned that was that
was maybe not the best way to go I

165
00:08:26.840 --> 00:08:28.320
tried to focus up a little bit.

166
00:08:28.320 --> 00:08:32.140
But you mentioned some things
like repeating the answer back,

167
00:08:32.140 --> 00:08:35.590
are there any other tips to
help us be better listeners?

168
00:08:35.590 --> 00:08:37.290
>> Yeah, one of the things that I use,

169
00:08:37.290 --> 00:08:41.590
great question,
is what I call calming the monkey mind.

170
00:08:41.590 --> 00:08:44.580
And the monkey mind is that voice that's
running in your head the whole time.

171
00:08:44.580 --> 00:08:46.890
Sometimes thinking of
what you're gonna answer.

172
00:08:46.890 --> 00:08:49.402
But it's going on and on and on,
and it sounds just like this.

173
00:08:51.634 --> 00:08:55.236
Okay right now you're going,
why isn't John talking, what's he doing,

174
00:08:55.236 --> 00:08:56.690
did my video freeze?

175
00:08:56.690 --> 00:08:59.840
That's the mind that runs in your head,
and one of the ways to be an exceptional

176
00:08:59.840 --> 00:09:04.000
listener is to get rid of the monkey
mind by replacing it with repeating what

177
00:09:04.000 --> 00:09:08.630
the other person is saying, over and over
again in your head as they're talking, so

178
00:09:08.630 --> 00:09:13.060
again I'll use my, okay they're talking
about a, talking about a and b.

179
00:09:13.060 --> 00:09:14.210
A, and b, and c.

180
00:09:14.210 --> 00:09:17.650
C is most important, a is second
important, b is third important.

181
00:09:17.650 --> 00:09:21.740
A,b,c and then when they stop you guys,
listen to you very carefully, and

182
00:09:21.740 --> 00:09:25.720
you talked about three things, a,b and
c, c is the most important to you.

183
00:09:25.720 --> 00:09:28.780
A is the second most important and
c is the most important.

184
00:09:28.780 --> 00:09:33.760
And what's neat about that is that they
might say it once You've heard it 10,

185
00:09:33.760 --> 00:09:37.370
15, 20 times in your mind by repeating it,
and it gives you a great memory for

186
00:09:37.370 --> 00:09:38.830
what you actually discussed.

187
00:09:38.830 --> 00:09:43.130
>> That's great John, so it sounds like
it's not only important how you listen,

188
00:09:43.130 --> 00:09:45.980
but kind of how your body's
reacting as well, and

189
00:09:45.980 --> 00:09:48.470
what you're doing while you're listening.

190
00:09:48.470 --> 00:09:51.570
>> Yeah,
actually they say that about 73% or more,

191
00:09:51.570 --> 00:09:56.320
could be all the way up to 93%
of communications is non verbal.

192
00:09:56.320 --> 00:10:00.680
Your body language,
eye contact, how open you are,

193
00:10:00.680 --> 00:10:05.130
your vocal inflection, your tone,
all of that adds to the message.

194
00:10:05.130 --> 00:10:08.940
And sometimes, if done poorly,
it can outdo the message,

195
00:10:08.940 --> 00:10:09.840
you can't actually hear it.

196
00:10:09.840 --> 00:10:12.470
So, when you look at it,
you wanna do things like this,

197
00:10:12.470 --> 00:10:14.990
and I'll look to you to be
able to do this together.

198
00:10:14.990 --> 00:10:19.170
You wanna open up and
have a good stance, you wanna be able to

199
00:10:19.170 --> 00:10:22.400
look the person in the eye, but not
staring down, just sort of make points.

200
00:10:22.400 --> 00:10:25.510
I think taking notes is critical if
you're gonna ask important questions,

201
00:10:25.510 --> 00:10:29.840
you wanna take good notes, so it's
an open stance, leaning in, taking notes,

202
00:10:29.840 --> 00:10:33.180
using nod heads,
keeping square to the person.

203
00:10:33.180 --> 00:10:36.460
Also using nonverbal, or verbal cues for

204
00:10:36.460 --> 00:10:40.080
showing them that you're listening
by going, mm-hm, yeah, I got that.

205
00:10:40.080 --> 00:10:41.170
I heard that, yeah, I'm listening.

206
00:10:41.170 --> 00:10:43.970
Not I agree, because if they say
something you don't agree with

207
00:10:43.970 --> 00:10:47.010
I've caught people that go,
yes, I agree, I agree, I agree.

208
00:10:47.010 --> 00:10:49.395
Then you say something you know they
don't agree with and they go, I agree.

209
00:10:49.395 --> 00:10:51.100
You're not listening to me.

210
00:10:51.100 --> 00:10:55.950
So you've gotta match your body language,
showing intently that you're listening.

211
00:10:55.950 --> 00:10:58.090
It's important I'm not
looking at anything.

212
00:10:58.090 --> 00:10:59.400
I'm not distracted.

213
00:10:59.400 --> 00:11:00.260
I'm taking notes.

214
00:11:00.260 --> 00:11:01.230
I'm smiling.

215
00:11:01.230 --> 00:11:05.590
I've got everything going,
while I'm paraphrasing, summarizing, and

216
00:11:05.590 --> 00:11:07.160
asking superb questions.

217
00:11:07.160 --> 00:11:09.410
If you can put that package together,

218
00:11:09.410 --> 00:11:13.080
that will really allow you to be
a much more effective communicator.

219
00:11:13.080 --> 00:11:16.020
>> Yeah and John, I think it's, really,
especially important to be taking notes

220
00:11:16.020 --> 00:11:19.770
when we're talking about more technical
topics like you might be in IT.

221
00:11:19.770 --> 00:11:23.230
Otherwise it maybe looks like you're
really not paying that much attention, or

222
00:11:23.230 --> 00:11:26.750
it could be worrisome to the person
presenting that you're not

223
00:11:26.750 --> 00:11:29.520
paying attention it makes me
think about in restaurants when

224
00:11:29.520 --> 00:11:34.210
the waiter is taking your order and
not writing down what you're saying, and

225
00:11:34.210 --> 00:11:37.240
I just know it's not gonna work
out well in that situation.

226
00:11:37.240 --> 00:11:38.880
>> Yeah, that's one of my pet peeves too.

227
00:11:38.880 --> 00:11:40.750
I love it when you got ten
people at a table, they come up,

228
00:11:40.750 --> 00:11:42.070
they just stand there,
you make your order.

229
00:11:42.070 --> 00:11:43.650
And you know this is not coming out right.

230
00:11:43.650 --> 00:11:45.300
There's no way it's gonna happen.

231
00:11:45.300 --> 00:11:48.240
Well, you make a great point because
this is exactly the same thing that

232
00:11:48.240 --> 00:11:52.820
happens if someone is, if you ask a great
question that's highly focused and

233
00:11:52.820 --> 00:11:57.000
someone takes the time to give you
an in depth, robust answer and

234
00:11:57.000 --> 00:11:59.720
you don't write anything down,
you know what you've just told them?

235
00:11:59.720 --> 00:12:01.170
I wasn't listening.

236
00:12:01.170 --> 00:12:03.950
So the key idea here is you want to
use all that body language I was

237
00:12:03.950 --> 00:12:08.140
talking about, leaning in, smiling, head
nods, and writing really good notes so

238
00:12:08.140 --> 00:12:11.690
that as you go between them they're
seeing you take all these notes.

239
00:12:11.690 --> 00:12:13.260
And I use a couple of tricks for this.

240
00:12:13.260 --> 00:12:17.570
If I hear them say something important
I will put a big star next to it.

241
00:12:17.570 --> 00:12:20.250
And that way as they're talking,
I've got it, and I'm nodding, and

242
00:12:20.250 --> 00:12:20.950
we're going along.

243
00:12:20.950 --> 00:12:23.339
And then they say it again,
I'll put another star and maybe a one.

244
00:12:23.339 --> 00:12:25.442
And then they'll keep going and
it'll be another star.

245
00:12:25.442 --> 00:12:29.789
And what that allows me to do is when
they've finally finished talking, I've got

246
00:12:29.789 --> 00:12:34.010
three or four areas that I know their
priorities, I've got four of five stars,

247
00:12:34.010 --> 00:12:37.042
I use a pound sign for numbers,
I got a big clock for time.

248
00:12:37.042 --> 00:12:39.824
So I say here's the numbers you
shared with me, the amount of time

249
00:12:39.824 --> 00:12:42.822
you think it'll take and
here's the three major things you covered.

250
00:12:42.822 --> 00:12:45.902
And that's a really clear
indication that I'd been listening,

251
00:12:45.902 --> 00:12:48.982
the information they're giving
me is extremely important, and

252
00:12:48.982 --> 00:12:52.290
I've written it all down,
which means I will remember it.

253
00:12:52.290 --> 00:12:54.080
>> Well,
I would've written down more here, John,

254
00:12:54.080 --> 00:12:55.990
but you've got some great
notes that you gave me.

255
00:12:55.990 --> 00:12:59.690
But I think, looking at the clock now,
we're about out of time for this episode.

256
00:12:59.690 --> 00:13:04.910
Are there any other key takeaways, looking
back at the things we've discussed,

257
00:13:04.910 --> 00:13:07.820
in terms of questions and
listening and body language?

258
00:13:07.820 --> 00:13:09.880
>> Yeah, I think the most important
thing to remember about this,

259
00:13:09.880 --> 00:13:11.610
this is a learned skill.

260
00:13:11.610 --> 00:13:13.470
This isn't something you
just practice once or

261
00:13:13.470 --> 00:13:16.220
try that it takes years of practice.

262
00:13:16.220 --> 00:13:19.530
I mean I've been teaching this for
20 years and I still struggle with it.

263
00:13:19.530 --> 00:13:23.500
So asking great questions,
being very curious,

264
00:13:23.500 --> 00:13:28.570
an intense listener, taking fantastic
notes and having wonderful body language.

265
00:13:28.570 --> 00:13:30.670
The more you practice it,
the better you'll get.

266
00:13:30.670 --> 00:13:32.770
And you can look up in a year or two and

267
00:13:32.770 --> 00:13:36.390
you will have completely changed the way
you communicate with other people,

268
00:13:36.390 --> 00:13:39.390
which will be a huge positive
boost in your career.

269
00:13:39.390 --> 00:13:40.000
>> Well thanks John,

270
00:13:40.000 --> 00:13:43.720
I think that's a great look at some of
the advanced communication skills and

271
00:13:43.720 --> 00:13:45.920
certainly it gonna help us in
our professional development.

272
00:13:45.920 --> 00:13:48.560
And I know we have a lot more
of professional development

273
00:13:48.560 --> 00:13:52.080
skills to talk about coming up in future
episodes but that's gonna do it for

274
00:13:52.080 --> 00:13:53.340
us, on this episode.

275
00:13:53.340 --> 00:13:55.730
So, going ahead and
signing off for BizProTV.

276
00:13:55.730 --> 00:13:57.440
I've been your host Peter Van Rysdam.

277
00:13:57.440 --> 00:13:58.610
>> And I'm John Spence.

278
00:13:58.610 --> 00:13:59.385

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.034
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.034 --> 00:00:09.327
Hello and welcome to BizProTV,
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam.

3
00:00:09.327 --> 00:00:13.180
And in today's episode we're continuing to
talk about professional development and

4
00:00:13.180 --> 00:00:16.730
specifically we're talking about
the essentials of accountability.

5
00:00:16.730 --> 00:00:18.900
And here to help us with
that we have John Spence,

6
00:00:18.900 --> 00:00:21.360
who we've met in the previous episodes.

7
00:00:21.360 --> 00:00:24.640
But he's a great speaker and
entrepreneur, and business man himself.

8
00:00:24.640 --> 00:00:26.130
So John, welcome.

9
00:00:26.130 --> 00:00:27.490
>> My pleasure to be here, Peter.

10
00:00:27.490 --> 00:00:30.710
>> So when we're talking about
the essentials of accountability,

11
00:00:30.710 --> 00:00:31.860
where do we start?

12
00:00:31.860 --> 00:00:34.390
>> Well, let me sort of frame this up.

13
00:00:34.390 --> 00:00:38.130
After 23 years I've worked with
companies all over the world.

14
00:00:38.130 --> 00:00:42.873
This is now the single biggest issue
that most organizations are faced

15
00:00:42.873 --> 00:00:46.003
with is lack of accountability and
disciplined execution.

16
00:00:46.003 --> 00:00:48.620
If you'd asked me about ten years ago,

17
00:00:48.620 --> 00:00:53.076
it was lack of a well communicated
vision and strategy for growth.

18
00:00:53.076 --> 00:00:55.396
And by the way a lot of people say but,
I'm not the CEO,

19
00:00:55.396 --> 00:00:56.522
the president or the owner.

20
00:00:56.522 --> 00:00:58.600
It's not my job to set the vision.

21
00:00:58.600 --> 00:00:59.800
The truth of the matter is,

22
00:00:59.800 --> 00:01:04.410
is if you lead one person, they look to
you to set the vision for the two of you.

23
00:01:04.410 --> 00:01:08.500
So the big problem I saw then
was lack of a well-communicated,

24
00:01:08.500 --> 00:01:11.270
compelling vision and strategy for growth.

25
00:01:11.270 --> 00:01:14.160
And no matter where you are in
the organization, you have to have that.

26
00:01:14.160 --> 00:01:18.350
If you had fast-forwarded a couple
more years, the biggest issue I saw

27
00:01:18.350 --> 00:01:22.060
was lack of courageous communication,
poor communication skills, and

28
00:01:22.060 --> 00:01:27.200
especially unwilling to talk about
difficult, uncomfortable, awkward things.

29
00:01:27.200 --> 00:01:29.570
They knew the economy was tough.

30
00:01:29.570 --> 00:01:31.100
They knew they might
have to do some layoffs.

31
00:01:31.100 --> 00:01:33.290
They knew there was gonna be
problems in their organization.

32
00:01:33.290 --> 00:01:34.530
They just didn't want to talk about it.

33
00:01:34.530 --> 00:01:37.560
They hoped it went away,
and hope is not a strategy.

34
00:01:37.560 --> 00:01:41.920
But you fast forward to today, single
biggest problem, disciplined execution,

35
00:01:41.920 --> 00:01:43.550
lack of accountability.

36
00:01:43.550 --> 00:01:46.060
So those are the things that when
I look at this, are the issues.

37
00:01:46.060 --> 00:01:47.180
And in accountability,

38
00:01:47.180 --> 00:01:50.830
there's five things it takes to
create a culture of accountability.

39
00:01:50.830 --> 00:01:53.500
So let's go through those right now.

40
00:01:53.500 --> 00:01:59.980
Number one Is 100% clarity plus
appropriate authority and resources.

41
00:01:59.980 --> 00:02:03.010
In other words, if you're gonna hold
someone accountable for something,

42
00:02:03.010 --> 00:02:05.730
especially something mission critical
that's gotta get done right,

43
00:02:05.730 --> 00:02:08.110
you need to sit down with that person and

44
00:02:08.110 --> 00:02:13.400
take the time to very clearly
outline your expectations.

45
00:02:13.400 --> 00:02:18.500
What is success looks like, how is success
measured, what's the timeline, what am

46
00:02:18.500 --> 00:02:23.020
I expecting to have happened at the end of
it, who is the user, what is the budget,

47
00:02:23.020 --> 00:02:27.640
how much resources you have available,
what level of authority do you have?

48
00:02:27.640 --> 00:02:33.110
>> So John, is that a one sided
conversation where if I'm your boss

49
00:02:33.110 --> 00:02:37.790
I'm telling you here is what I expect of
you or is this kind of a two way street?

50
00:02:37.790 --> 00:02:40.510
>> Well at first it's one way.

51
00:02:40.510 --> 00:02:42.790
As the leader the manager lays this out.

52
00:02:42.790 --> 00:02:46.070
Now comes step two after
you've gotten 100% clarity

53
00:02:46.070 --> 00:02:50.280
plus appropriate authority and
resources, next step is 100% agreement.

54
00:02:50.280 --> 00:02:52.790
And Peter this is where there
is a discussion about it.

55
00:02:52.790 --> 00:02:54.820
And what you want to have
happen is you want that person

56
00:02:54.820 --> 00:02:57.620
you're holding accountable to
sit down in front of you and

57
00:02:57.620 --> 00:03:01.330
say I understand exactly
what success looks like.

58
00:03:01.330 --> 00:03:06.640
I understand the metrics, the timeline,
who the user is, what the budget is.

59
00:03:06.640 --> 00:03:10.790
I believe, and here's where it is,
I believe this is a reasonable goal and

60
00:03:10.790 --> 00:03:13.250
I accept 100% accountability.

61
00:03:13.250 --> 00:03:16.400
Until you get those two things
you don't have accountability so

62
00:03:16.400 --> 00:03:18.750
this is the part where it is a discussion.

63
00:03:18.750 --> 00:03:21.190
At some level it's a negotiation.

64
00:03:21.190 --> 00:03:24.690
The boss, the manager might say this
is non negotiable, this part, but

65
00:03:24.690 --> 00:03:29.550
they talk until, and this is critical, the
person says I understand this completely

66
00:03:29.550 --> 00:03:32.460
and I accept 100% accountability.

67
00:03:32.460 --> 00:03:36.720
>> And you mentioned the key point there
that in order to have success with this,

68
00:03:36.720 --> 00:03:37.910
you've gotta be able to track it.

69
00:03:37.910 --> 00:03:41.250
So you've gotta come up with,
at that meeting, what are those metrics.

70
00:03:41.250 --> 00:03:44.560
And so for example in IT,
it might be up time,

71
00:03:44.560 --> 00:03:49.050
it might be response time to support
tickets and things like that.

72
00:03:49.050 --> 00:03:52.010
But what are the ways to kind of

73
00:03:52.010 --> 00:03:54.980
make sure that you're on the same
page in terms of the accountability?

74
00:03:54.980 --> 00:03:57.310
>> You're exactly right, and
that's actually step three.

75
00:03:57.310 --> 00:03:59.850
And there's a couple things about
the metrics in accountability.

76
00:03:59.850 --> 00:04:01.800
First one is the metrics and

77
00:04:01.800 --> 00:04:05.780
the measurements must be binary,
in a term you all know very well.

78
00:04:05.780 --> 00:04:09.550
It's zero or one, yes or no, no guessing.

79
00:04:09.550 --> 00:04:11.200
One of my favorite phrases is and

80
00:04:11.200 --> 00:04:15.840
this goes perfectly in the IT world is,
ambiguity breeds mediocrity.

81
00:04:15.840 --> 00:04:19.600
So step three then you've got 100%
clarity plus appropriate authority and

82
00:04:19.600 --> 00:04:23.950
resources 100% agreements,
that step three then is track and post.

83
00:04:23.950 --> 00:04:26.590
And there is two key ideas
around track and post.

84
00:04:26.590 --> 00:04:29.832
The first one is you gotta make
it really easy to understand.

85
00:04:29.832 --> 00:04:33.940
Those metrics are binary, there's no
guessing, there's no ambiguity and

86
00:04:33.940 --> 00:04:36.930
the way I think about it is they've
gotta be able to look at the goals,

87
00:04:36.930 --> 00:04:40.620
their major goals, and within three
seconds see how they're doing.

88
00:04:40.620 --> 00:04:44.220
So the one I normally use is it's green,
yellow, red.

89
00:04:44.220 --> 00:04:45.670
You're either doing great,
you're on track,

90
00:04:45.670 --> 00:04:47.520
you're on time, you're doing fantastic.

91
00:04:47.520 --> 00:04:49.980
Yellow you're in a cautionary,
we're worried, we're concerned.

92
00:04:49.980 --> 00:04:51.730
Or red you're falling behind.

93
00:04:51.730 --> 00:04:54.020
And you are about to get in trouble.

94
00:04:54.020 --> 00:04:58.180
So step one then in the track a post
is make it super easy to understand.

95
00:04:58.180 --> 00:05:00.860
Step two then is highly visible.

96
00:05:00.860 --> 00:05:05.420
It's everywhere, it's posted everywhere
for everyone to see, from the highest

97
00:05:05.420 --> 00:05:08.520
person in the organization or
the team, to the lowest person.

98
00:05:08.520 --> 00:05:13.030
Everybody's major goals are posted
everywhere, and it's exceedingly

99
00:05:13.030 --> 00:05:17.890
clear to see when you look at it exactly
where everyone stands against those goals.

100
00:05:17.890 --> 00:05:21.420
>> And I think it's important what you
said about kind of the red, yellow,

101
00:05:21.420 --> 00:05:25.230
green to get an idea as you're going
because if you give me this goal and

102
00:05:25.230 --> 00:05:28.080
this new task,
I might not be an expert at it by day one.

103
00:05:28.080 --> 00:05:30.730
But to kind of see where those
areas that I need to improve.

104
00:05:30.730 --> 00:05:34.690
So is there a kind of time frame that
you recommend for these types of goals?

105
00:05:34.690 --> 00:05:36.763
Is this something that,
this is your weekly goal or

106
00:05:36.763 --> 00:05:39.350
this is your quarterly goal,
or your yearly goal?

107
00:05:39.350 --> 00:05:43.150
>> Well what you want to look at is
the major goals, the stuff that's gonna

108
00:05:43.150 --> 00:05:45.600
move the organization,
the team, the business forward.

109
00:05:45.600 --> 00:05:48.300
We don't want to track every goal
We want to track the make or

110
00:05:48.300 --> 00:05:50.970
break stuff that's gonna
have the biggest impact.

111
00:05:50.970 --> 00:05:53.760
My idea there to would be is to
track it as often as possible.

112
00:05:53.760 --> 00:05:59.060
Maybe not daily but definitely weekly and
a bid minimum of monthly.

113
00:05:59.060 --> 00:06:02.090
Now, here's what happen to most of the
organizations when you tell people let's

114
00:06:02.090 --> 00:06:03.720
use weekly.

115
00:06:03.720 --> 00:06:07.460
Every single week we're gonna take
your goals, put them on a big thing so

116
00:06:07.460 --> 00:06:10.360
everybody can see it and its gonna be
really easy to tell if you're green,

117
00:06:10.360 --> 00:06:11.430
yellow, or red.

118
00:06:11.430 --> 00:06:13.020
And they go!

119
00:06:13.020 --> 00:06:15.420
Everyone's gonna see my goals and
how I'm doing.

120
00:06:15.420 --> 00:06:17.880
Most people get scared, or
actually, here's what happens.

121
00:06:17.880 --> 00:06:20.810
About 10% of the people in
the organization love it,

122
00:06:20.810 --> 00:06:22.400
because they're the superstars.

123
00:06:22.400 --> 00:06:24.600
They're the ones that are always
gonna be green, green, green, green.

124
00:06:24.600 --> 00:06:26.247
They get to stand next to it and
go look, I'm Mr. Green.

125
00:06:26.247 --> 00:06:29.138
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Then you're gonna have a whole

126
00:06:29.138 --> 00:06:31.270
bunch of people in
the middle organization,

127
00:06:31.270 --> 00:06:35.010
70 to 80% that freak out,
they look like a deer in headlights!

128
00:06:35.010 --> 00:06:37.678
And then you've got about
10% at the bottom that fall

129
00:06:37.678 --> 00:06:41.594
on the ground like a two-year-old with a
wet diaper [SOUND] and that's the ones you

130
00:06:41.594 --> 00:06:45.534
go it's been a pleasure working with you
and you make them available to industry.

131
00:06:45.534 --> 00:06:49.560
Because what they've just told you is I'm
mediocre and now everyone's going to see.

132
00:06:49.560 --> 00:06:53.270
I'm gonna be yellow, red, yellow, red,
yellow, red So that's the next step,

133
00:06:53.270 --> 00:06:55.440
step three is track and post.

134
00:06:55.440 --> 00:06:59.410
And now we're gonna go to step four,
which is when people freak out like that,

135
00:06:59.410 --> 00:07:03.250
instead of saying, hey you slipped from
green to yellow, you're in trouble.

136
00:07:03.250 --> 00:07:06.820
Or you're slipping into yellow and
we're gonna come and yell at you.

137
00:07:06.820 --> 00:07:10.240
Step number fours is coach,
mentor, train, support.

138
00:07:10.240 --> 00:07:13.810
In other words slipping from green to
yellow, doesn't get you into trouble,

139
00:07:13.810 --> 00:07:15.040
it gets you help.

140
00:07:15.040 --> 00:07:18.580
That people come rushing into support you,
to assist you, you get a coach,

141
00:07:18.580 --> 00:07:22.190
you get a mentor, you get to watch
some more programs on ITProTV.

142
00:07:22.190 --> 00:07:25.650
We do everything we can to
get you back up into green.

143
00:07:25.650 --> 00:07:29.370
And what eventually happens is, and
it takes a while people realizing

144
00:07:29.370 --> 00:07:33.620
that the tracking isn't for punishment,
the tracking is for help and support, and

145
00:07:33.620 --> 00:07:36.010
Peter, as soon as they got to that level,
you know what they want?

146
00:07:36.010 --> 00:07:36.640
More tracking.

147
00:07:36.640 --> 00:07:38.100
>> More tracking, exactly.

148
00:07:38.100 --> 00:07:41.930
Well, and so what happens then, at the end
of this period when obviously, like you

149
00:07:41.930 --> 00:07:45.700
said, if things are yellow or red,
you've got some things to take care of,

150
00:07:45.700 --> 00:07:48.990
but If it's green, there's also
some steps you can take as well.

151
00:07:48.990 --> 00:07:52.560
>> Yeah, the key idea here
is you wanna do two things.

152
00:07:52.560 --> 00:07:55.560
With green,
is you wanna celebrate success lavishly.

153
00:07:55.560 --> 00:07:58.390
When I say lavishly,
I don't mean throwing around $100 bills or

154
00:07:58.390 --> 00:07:59.840
giving somebody a massive bonus.

155
00:07:59.840 --> 00:08:01.130
Although, that's nice.

156
00:08:01.130 --> 00:08:04.680
What I'm saying is a handshake,
a pat on the back, a thank you card,

157
00:08:04.680 --> 00:08:07.540
some flex time,
dinner out with their significant other.

158
00:08:07.540 --> 00:08:10.190
Something to say you made a promise.

159
00:08:10.190 --> 00:08:11.130
You kept the promise.

160
00:08:11.130 --> 00:08:13.220
You delivered on your goals.

161
00:08:13.220 --> 00:08:14.990
Here is the reward, here is the bonus.

162
00:08:14.990 --> 00:08:15.940
Thank you very much.

163
00:08:15.940 --> 00:08:19.380
So you celebrate both big and small wins.

164
00:08:19.380 --> 00:08:23.120
The other side of that is,
you must deal decisively with mediocrity.

165
00:08:23.120 --> 00:08:26.250
That if someone is consistently
yellow red, yellow red.

166
00:08:26.250 --> 00:08:28.900
You're coaching, you're mentoring,
you're training, you're supporting.

167
00:08:28.900 --> 00:08:30.130
Everyone on the team is helping.

168
00:08:30.130 --> 00:08:33.100
They're doing everything they can
to get them back up in the green.

169
00:08:33.100 --> 00:08:35.540
And I can't get them back up into green

170
00:08:35.540 --> 00:08:39.510
then when you do either turn them on
a performance plan or terminate them,

171
00:08:39.510 --> 00:08:42.970
remove them from the organization,
nobody feels bad about it.

172
00:08:42.970 --> 00:08:47.020
Because it's obvious you've been spending
weeks or months supporting them,

173
00:08:47.020 --> 00:08:49.810
helping them, trying to get them better so
it doesn't come as a shock.

174
00:08:49.810 --> 00:08:52.700
I don't quote a lot of CEOs, but I do have

175
00:08:52.700 --> 00:08:57.680
one favorite Jack Welch quote from GE I
never fired anybody who was surprised.

176
00:08:57.680 --> 00:09:01.760
And this tracking and posting makes it
simple to everyone in the organization,

177
00:09:01.760 --> 00:09:05.020
to see who's doing well, why they get a
promotion, why they might get more money,

178
00:09:05.020 --> 00:09:07.010
and to see who's struggling and

179
00:09:07.010 --> 00:09:10.770
to clearly see that everybody tried to
help the person that was struggling and

180
00:09:10.770 --> 00:09:13.160
they didn't make it,
which is why they're not here anymore.

181
00:09:13.160 --> 00:09:14.920
>> It makes a lot of sense.

182
00:09:14.920 --> 00:09:19.920
So, this sounds like it's not just a
change in some procedural things that you

183
00:09:19.920 --> 00:09:22.470
do to your company but
it's a shift in the culture.

184
00:09:22.470 --> 00:09:27.030
>> Yeah, this is all around creating
a culture of accountability which is if

185
00:09:27.030 --> 00:09:31.930
we go to most business leaders today and I
asked them what they look for an employee,

186
00:09:31.930 --> 00:09:35.430
of course they want competence, they want
someone who's proactive in all things but

187
00:09:35.430 --> 00:09:38.290
I can boil it all down to two words
>> I want people with

188
00:09:38.290 --> 00:09:39.490
an ownership mentality.

189
00:09:39.490 --> 00:09:44.880
And what we're trying to create here
is a culture of extreme customer focus,

190
00:09:44.880 --> 00:09:48.890
where people are highly talented and
competent, getting better every day,

191
00:09:48.890 --> 00:09:53.220
they understand their clear goals, and
then they're very disciplined about

192
00:09:53.220 --> 00:09:57.590
executing on those goals and taking
high levels of personal accountability.

193
00:09:57.590 --> 00:09:59.270
>> Great John, I appreciate that and

194
00:09:59.270 --> 00:10:02.480
it looks like we're getting close to
running out of time for this episode,

195
00:10:02.480 --> 00:10:06.730
so any last key take aways on
the essentials of accountability here?

196
00:10:06.730 --> 00:10:10.660
>> Yeah, the thing that a lot of people
struggle with is they think holding other

197
00:10:10.660 --> 00:10:15.920
people accountable makes them mean or
tough or someone to be feared.

198
00:10:15.920 --> 00:10:19.226
And the truth of the matter is when
you use the process I just laid out,

199
00:10:19.226 --> 00:10:23.045
It's very fair, it's very reasonable,
there's no emotion involved in it,

200
00:10:23.045 --> 00:10:26.066
there's no politics, and
all you're doing is holding people

201
00:10:26.066 --> 00:10:29.920
accountable to the promises they made
to help the business be successful.

202
00:10:29.920 --> 00:10:31.920
>> Yeah, I think that's one
of the key points there.

203
00:10:31.920 --> 00:10:34.310
There's gonna be that finger pointing
because at the end of the day,

204
00:10:34.310 --> 00:10:37.190
this is what they agreed to, so
they're only being accountable for

205
00:10:37.190 --> 00:10:38.870
the things that they said
they'll be accountable for.

206
00:10:38.870 --> 00:10:41.480
So I think that's a great place
to go ahead and leave off for

207
00:10:41.480 --> 00:10:44.010
this episode though, for
the essentials of accountability.

208
00:10:44.010 --> 00:10:46.880
We've got a lot more professional
development skills coming your way with

209
00:10:46.880 --> 00:10:49.520
John, so go ahead and
stay tuned to BizProTV.

210
00:10:49.520 --> 00:10:50.470
But I'm signing off now.

211
00:10:50.470 --> 00:10:52.100
I've been Peter VanRysdam.

212
00:10:52.100 --> 00:10:52.820
>> I'm John Spence.

213
00:10:52.820 --> 00:10:53.817
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.369
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.369 --> 00:00:07.840
Hello and welcome to BizProTV.

3
00:00:07.840 --> 00:00:09.610
I'm your host, Peter Van Rysdam.

4
00:00:09.610 --> 00:00:12.610
And today we're continuing our
series on professional development.

5
00:00:12.610 --> 00:00:16.282
And specifically today, we're gonna talk
about achieving business excellence.

6
00:00:16.282 --> 00:00:19.930
And here to help us do that is someone
who, I think has done that for himself,

7
00:00:19.930 --> 00:00:20.860
Mr. John Spence.

8
00:00:20.860 --> 00:00:21.690
John, how you doing today?

9
00:00:21.690 --> 00:00:22.520
>> Great, Peter, how are you?

10
00:00:22.520 --> 00:00:23.620
>> Good, great, thanks.

11
00:00:23.620 --> 00:00:25.770
Now, achieving business excellence,
that's easy,

12
00:00:25.770 --> 00:00:27.815
we should be able to knock
that out here in 20 minutes.

13
00:00:27.815 --> 00:00:29.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> Where do we start?

14
00:00:29.270 --> 00:00:32.350
>> Well,
as we've talked about this before,

15
00:00:32.350 --> 00:00:35.440
I've built my entire career on
making complex things simple.

16
00:00:35.440 --> 00:00:38.570
And all of this started
after I wrote my first book.

17
00:00:38.570 --> 00:00:40.560
And that book was 53,518 words long.

18
00:00:40.560 --> 00:00:43.290
I didn't actually type it.

19
00:00:43.290 --> 00:00:46.030
I spoke it using a dictation software.

20
00:00:46.030 --> 00:00:50.590
And when I finished that book, I loaded it
into this software program called Wordle.

21
00:00:50.590 --> 00:00:54.750
And what what Wordle does, it allows you
to put the text of a document in and

22
00:00:54.750 --> 00:00:58.040
it scans it, takes out the uhs and
the thes and all that stuff, and

23
00:00:58.040 --> 00:01:02.360
it creates a pattern of the ideas and
their picture of it, a word cloud.

24
00:01:02.360 --> 00:01:05.790
And the bigger the word is in the word
cloud the more times it was in the text.

25
00:01:05.790 --> 00:01:09.390
So I loaded my 53,518 words in there.

26
00:01:09.390 --> 00:01:13.470
And it gave me this really cool picture
of my entire book, all the main ideas.

27
00:01:13.470 --> 00:01:16.160
And I'm a visual learner,
so that was really cool.

28
00:01:16.160 --> 00:01:17.885
But then I realized I'm not that smart.

29
00:01:17.885 --> 00:01:22.880
[LAUGH] So I went to a couple of my
friends, some of the top authors, CEOs,

30
00:01:22.880 --> 00:01:27.760
and I asked them for their copies
of their books, or memos, or ideas.

31
00:01:27.760 --> 00:01:31.560
I won't drag you through the whole thing,
but instead of 53,000 words

32
00:01:31.560 --> 00:01:36.140
I loaded about 240,000 pages into Wordle,
from all the top business thinkers,

33
00:01:36.140 --> 00:01:40.240
all the top business books in the world,
and it gave me a word cloud.

34
00:01:40.240 --> 00:01:43.270
And I looked at that word cloud and
it was still too complex.

35
00:01:43.270 --> 00:01:46.870
So I worked on it, worked on it, and I
got it down to what I call my formula for

36
00:01:46.870 --> 00:01:48.230
business excellence.

37
00:01:48.230 --> 00:01:52.920
And this are four things that I believe
are fundamental to building a successful

38
00:01:52.920 --> 00:01:57.330
organization, whether it's a few people,
a few hundred or a hundred thousand.

39
00:01:57.330 --> 00:02:00.690
So, here's the equation and
then I'll explain it quickly.

40
00:02:00.690 --> 00:02:04.600
It's in parenthesis for those of you that
are highly analytical to know about math,

41
00:02:04.600 --> 00:02:06.200
which I don't.

42
00:02:06.200 --> 00:02:13.130
It's T Plus C plus ECF multiplied by DE.

43
00:02:13.130 --> 00:02:14.610
So let's go through that.

44
00:02:14.610 --> 00:02:16.100
First one is tower.

45
00:02:16.100 --> 00:02:19.790
And for most organizations and
especially the ones you all work for

46
00:02:19.790 --> 00:02:24.510
in the IT division,
the success of the business is directly

47
00:02:24.510 --> 00:02:29.270
tied to the quality of people that you
can get, grow and keep on your team.

48
00:02:29.270 --> 00:02:32.890
Other people can buy the same hardware,
they can buy the same software, but

49
00:02:32.890 --> 00:02:37.420
what they can't buy is super-talented
people and growing them.

50
00:02:37.420 --> 00:02:40.190
That's one of the only sustainable
competitive advantages

51
00:02:40.190 --> 00:02:43.130
left to most businesses,
really good talented people.

52
00:02:43.130 --> 00:02:46.480
So step one is, and again even if
you don't run the organization,

53
00:02:46.480 --> 00:02:50.602
just talking about your team or two or
three people working on a project.

54
00:02:50.602 --> 00:02:53.350
You wanna get the best
people you can possibly get.

55
00:02:53.350 --> 00:02:54.580
The top talent and

56
00:02:54.580 --> 00:02:59.410
then the big caveat to this,
more important is you need to be talent.

57
00:02:59.410 --> 00:03:02.810
You've got to constantly be reading,
studying, upgrading your skills,

58
00:03:02.810 --> 00:03:06.790
upgrading your communication skills,
your professional skills, your IT skills.

59
00:03:06.790 --> 00:03:09.840
Constantly learning and
growing and improving, so

60
00:03:09.840 --> 00:03:13.050
that you're recognized as
talent in the organization.

61
00:03:13.050 --> 00:03:17.940
The next letter is C, and
what C stands for is culture.

62
00:03:17.940 --> 00:03:20.238
And there's two sides to the culture coin.

63
00:03:20.238 --> 00:03:25.017
Side one is the culture that employees
want and there's been a ton of studies and

64
00:03:25.017 --> 00:03:26.500
research on this.

65
00:03:26.500 --> 00:03:29.650
And I'll break it down here to seven or
eight key ideas

66
00:03:29.650 --> 00:03:33.310
of what most employees look for in
a business that they want to work in and

67
00:03:33.310 --> 00:03:36.530
has what they we consider
a great place to work.

68
00:03:36.530 --> 00:03:39.280
First of all, it's a fun place to work and
that doesn't mean we got

69
00:03:39.280 --> 00:03:42.650
rock climbing walls and sushi bars and
everything else, so that's nice.

70
00:03:42.650 --> 00:03:46.210
But what it really means,
in the way I can phrase this is,

71
00:03:46.210 --> 00:03:48.490
people smile just as much when they
come to work as when they leave.

72
00:03:48.490 --> 00:03:51.410
They look forward to getting there in the
morning, they're excited about their job,

73
00:03:51.410 --> 00:03:53.840
the work they're doing,
who they work with,

74
00:03:53.840 --> 00:03:57.340
which means also that they work with a lot
of people they consider their friends,

75
00:03:57.340 --> 00:03:59.300
some of them even their best friend.

76
00:03:59.300 --> 00:04:03.030
They take pride in the organization,
they're proud of the work they do, they

77
00:04:03.030 --> 00:04:06.690
get a lot of praise for great work, and
they feel like their work is meaningful.

78
00:04:06.690 --> 00:04:07.950
And I can bring you a couple more but

79
00:04:07.950 --> 00:04:11.470
it gives you an idea of
what do employees look for?

80
00:04:11.470 --> 00:04:16.330
Now the other side of that coin is what do
employers look for, bosses and managers?

81
00:04:16.330 --> 00:04:17.660
And it's pretty simple.

82
00:04:17.660 --> 00:04:21.570
They want top talent with
an ownership mentality.

83
00:04:21.570 --> 00:04:24.500
People that are pro active,
innovative, creative,

84
00:04:24.500 --> 00:04:27.110
don't wait to be told what to do,
go out and do it.

85
00:04:27.110 --> 00:04:29.410
And look at the business
as if it were their own.

86
00:04:29.410 --> 00:04:32.780
Every dollar that comes in, every bit
of their budget they wanna maximize

87
00:04:32.780 --> 00:04:35.760
efficiency and effectiveness,
minimize waste.

88
00:04:35.760 --> 00:04:39.510
So when you look at creating a great
culture, it's not only a great culture for

89
00:04:39.510 --> 00:04:42.550
the employees where they love to
come to work and do great work.

90
00:04:42.550 --> 00:04:46.220
But it's also a culture that
has disciplined execution and

91
00:04:46.220 --> 00:04:49.010
delivers the results and
has accountability.

92
00:04:49.010 --> 00:04:51.070
And makes sure that
the business is going forward.

93
00:04:51.070 --> 00:04:52.350
>> But
I think at the end of the day, John,

94
00:04:52.350 --> 00:04:54.966
we can all agree that a foosball table-
>> [LAUGH]

95
00:04:54.966 --> 00:04:56.537
>> - is a great part of any company

96
00:04:56.537 --> 00:04:57.136
culture.

97
00:04:57.136 --> 00:05:02.165
>> [CROSSTALK] I might say can-
>> But moving forward,

98
00:05:02.165 --> 00:05:06.450
I'm looking at ECF and I'm trying to
guess what that is and I have no idea.

99
00:05:06.450 --> 00:05:06.979
So help me out.

100
00:05:08.110 --> 00:05:11.080
>> ECF stands for
Extreme Customer Focus or

101
00:05:11.080 --> 00:05:13.700
you could call it in your
world extreme client focus.

102
00:05:14.750 --> 00:05:17.860
Here is what I always is whoever
understands their customers,

103
00:05:17.860 --> 00:05:21.130
the people they serve the best
has a huge advantage.

104
00:05:21.130 --> 00:05:23.800
So the idea here is you
wanna service mindset,

105
00:05:23.800 --> 00:05:27.600
you wanna deeply understand the people
that you deliver you work for,

106
00:05:27.600 --> 00:05:31.580
understand their needs, their wants,
their fears, their wishes, their desires.

107
00:05:31.580 --> 00:05:35.160
The more focused you are on your client,
your customer.

108
00:05:35.160 --> 00:05:38.900
The better job you can be in
delivering exactly what they need.

109
00:05:38.900 --> 00:05:41.700
And this is an extremely
important part of a culture.

110
00:05:41.700 --> 00:05:44.230
Because at the end of the day,
it's the people that you serve

111
00:05:44.230 --> 00:05:47.200
that pay all the bills, or
allow you to keep your job.

112
00:05:47.200 --> 00:05:48.660
So we take those three things.

113
00:05:48.660 --> 00:05:52.320
We've got top talent with
a winning culture, both for

114
00:05:52.320 --> 00:05:56.870
employees, and for the business,
that is extremely customer client focused.

115
00:05:56.870 --> 00:05:59.800
And then you multiply it
by disciplined execution.

116
00:05:59.800 --> 00:06:04.315
By having a team that has both
personal accountability, plus mutual

117
00:06:04.315 --> 00:06:07.595
accountability, where everybody knows
what they're trying to achieve.

118
00:06:07.595 --> 00:06:09.165
And they come in everyday with, and

119
00:06:09.165 --> 00:06:13.755
they're focused on it, they build it into
the DNA of the organization, it's on

120
00:06:13.755 --> 00:06:18.760
all of the meeting agendas and notes that
everything is around not just talking, but

121
00:06:18.760 --> 00:06:21.210
actually delivering what
they promise to deliver.

122
00:06:21.210 --> 00:06:22.800
>> Well you said at the beginning,

123
00:06:22.800 --> 00:06:27.030
well I joked that we can't do business
excellence in 20 minutes here.

124
00:06:27.030 --> 00:06:29.853
But I think like I said
you simplified it and

125
00:06:29.853 --> 00:06:33.938
put in a little container here
where we kind of understand it.

126
00:06:33.938 --> 00:06:38.317
And I think the difficult part now is
figuring out how to find the great talent

127
00:06:38.317 --> 00:06:42.080
and how to build that company culture and
kind of get that focus and

128
00:06:42.080 --> 00:06:46.870
that binding from the team but any other
tips here for building those things.

129
00:06:46.870 --> 00:06:51.020
>> Well, the idea here is,
these aren't the only four things.

130
00:06:51.020 --> 00:06:53.680
You've still gotta have good financial
management, quality products and

131
00:06:53.680 --> 00:06:56.450
services, all those sort of things.

132
00:06:56.450 --> 00:07:00.040
But I believe that if you look at this
equation, and on a scale of one to ten,

133
00:07:00.040 --> 00:07:01.980
with ten being world class.

134
00:07:01.980 --> 00:07:03.900
You've gotta be a solid eight, nine, or

135
00:07:03.900 --> 00:07:08.832
a ten ifs you wanted to grow a succesfull
business and sustain that success.

136
00:07:08.832 --> 00:07:11.840
>> All right John that's really helpful
and I think I understand the culture and

137
00:07:11.840 --> 00:07:13.900
I understand getting good talent.

138
00:07:13.900 --> 00:07:17.874
But the extreme customer focus,
that's a little more nebulous for me,

139
00:07:17.874 --> 00:07:20.558
can you help me honing on
by what you mean by that?

140
00:07:20.558 --> 00:07:23.253
>> Peter, when you look at extreme
customer focus we're gonna take it down

141
00:07:23.253 --> 00:07:25.170
another level and go a little bit deeper.

142
00:07:25.170 --> 00:07:28.950
There's three elements underneath
that that I call the web of value.

143
00:07:28.950 --> 00:07:31.620
The first one is very much like
what I was talking about before.

144
00:07:31.620 --> 00:07:35.710
It's called VOC and that stands for
the Voice of the Customer.

145
00:07:35.710 --> 00:07:40.120
That means that if you really wanna deeply
understand the needs of your customer,

146
00:07:40.120 --> 00:07:42.810
you've gotta capture their
voice in lots and lots of ways.

147
00:07:42.810 --> 00:07:44.552
Through one on ones, surveys,

148
00:07:44.552 --> 00:07:48.683
net promoter scores VIP meeting's
taking folks to lunch, whatever it is,

149
00:07:48.683 --> 00:07:53.138
every method could possibly use to deeply
understand there needs, there wants,

150
00:07:53.138 --> 00:07:57.656
their wishes, their fears, their desires
because the more you understand that,

151
00:07:57.656 --> 00:08:00.522
as I said,
the better job you can do in serving them.

152
00:08:00.522 --> 00:08:03.779
So that's VOC,
own the Voice of the Customer.

153
00:08:03.779 --> 00:08:07.920
The next one is MOT which stands for
Moments of Truth.

154
00:08:07.920 --> 00:08:11.370
And many people tell me this is one
of the most powerful ideas I teach.

155
00:08:12.380 --> 00:08:15.330
This came from a gentleman
named Jan Carlzon, years and

156
00:08:15.330 --> 00:08:19.140
years ago, he was named the CEO
of Scandinavian Airway.

157
00:08:19.140 --> 00:08:23.190
And at the time, Scandinavian Airway
was in serious financial trouble And

158
00:08:23.190 --> 00:08:26.410
he looked at it and said, if we're
going to have to rebuild this company,

159
00:08:26.410 --> 00:08:29.370
why don't we rebuild it on the shoulders
of the very best customers,

160
00:08:29.370 --> 00:08:33.770
which is someone like me who travels
200 days a year, the business traveler.

161
00:08:33.770 --> 00:08:37.717
And he said, let's look at it and
we'll look at all of the touch points,

162
00:08:37.717 --> 00:08:41.989
all of the places we interact with that
customer and out of that we'll identify

163
00:08:41.989 --> 00:08:46.860
the three, four, five moments of truth
that make or break the relationship.

164
00:08:46.860 --> 00:08:50.600
So I like to use the example of
going to a restaurant for this.

165
00:08:50.600 --> 00:08:53.620
And I did the research if you
would take your family or

166
00:08:53.620 --> 00:08:55.990
friends out to a restaurant for dinner.

167
00:08:55.990 --> 00:08:58.620
There's about 170 touch points.

168
00:08:58.620 --> 00:09:00.650
From is it easy to find the place?

169
00:09:00.650 --> 00:09:01.820
Is the signage bright?

170
00:09:01.820 --> 00:09:03.580
Is it easy to drive in and out?

171
00:09:03.580 --> 00:09:05.100
Is the parking lot clean?

172
00:09:05.100 --> 00:09:06.990
Is the shrubbery attractive?

173
00:09:06.990 --> 00:09:08.230
Do they greet you at the door?

174
00:09:08.230 --> 00:09:11.360
All of those are touch points but
in pretty much

175
00:09:11.360 --> 00:09:15.420
every restaurant on the face of the earth
there's only four moments of truth.

176
00:09:15.420 --> 00:09:18.840
Four things they must do flawlessly
if they wanna take someone and

177
00:09:18.840 --> 00:09:21.380
turn them into a customer evangelists.

178
00:09:21.380 --> 00:09:24.530
Someone who loves the restaurant,
recommends it to all their friends,

179
00:09:24.530 --> 00:09:28.030
comes back all the time,
becomes a real regular, a patron.

180
00:09:28.030 --> 00:09:32.330
So and I've asked thousands of people
this and they all pretty much get it,

181
00:09:32.330 --> 00:09:33.460
and here they are.

182
00:09:33.460 --> 00:09:40.010
Good quality food, good service,
reasonable prices, cleanliness, that's it.

183
00:09:40.010 --> 00:09:44.100
Those are the four things that most people
look for in a restaurant if they're going

184
00:09:44.100 --> 00:09:46.610
to become a patron and
come back over and over again.

185
00:09:46.610 --> 00:09:49.980
So if I went to a restaurant and
let's say, Peter, I took you, you and

186
00:09:49.980 --> 00:09:50.940
I went out to dinner.

187
00:09:50.940 --> 00:09:52.450
>> Thank you.
>> Yep, be my pleasure.

188
00:09:52.450 --> 00:09:53.210
What do you like?

189
00:09:53.210 --> 00:09:54.930
What's your favorite type of food?

190
00:09:54.930 --> 00:09:56.010
>> Let's go Steakhouse.

191
00:09:56.010 --> 00:10:00.770
Steakhouse, so we go to the steakhouse
they great us at the door it's beautiful

192
00:10:00.770 --> 00:10:05.360
they got you know it's a country western
steakhouse there are folks out front

193
00:10:05.360 --> 00:10:07.490
ding ding you know playing country music.

194
00:10:07.490 --> 00:10:09.570
They're all dressed in cowboys hats.

195
00:10:09.570 --> 00:10:14.547
The service is amazing they sit us down
right away, keep the beer ice cold.

196
00:10:14.547 --> 00:10:17.470
We look at the menu the prices
are really reasonable.

197
00:10:17.470 --> 00:10:21.070
You order a huge steak, it comes out
it is the best steak you've ever had.

198
00:10:21.070 --> 00:10:23.510
Juicy, delicious, cooked perfectly.

199
00:10:23.510 --> 00:10:24.640
Then you get up to use the restroom.

200
00:10:24.640 --> 00:10:27.000
You go in there, it looks like
nobody's cleaned it in five years.

201
00:10:27.000 --> 00:10:27.970
It's disgusting.

202
00:10:27.970 --> 00:10:29.320
It's nasty.

203
00:10:29.320 --> 00:10:31.120
Are you ever going there again?

204
00:10:31.120 --> 00:10:31.930
>> Probably not.

205
00:10:31.930 --> 00:10:33.077
Or maybe take out.

206
00:10:33.077 --> 00:10:37.750
>> [LAUGH] Well, you look at it and say,
if this is what the bathroom looks like,

207
00:10:37.750 --> 00:10:39.430
I wonder what the kitchen looks like.

208
00:10:39.430 --> 00:10:41.810
And for most people that's a no-go.

209
00:10:41.810 --> 00:10:42.890
I'm never going back there again.

210
00:10:42.890 --> 00:10:45.100
The food was great, the service is great,
the price reasonable, but

211
00:10:45.100 --> 00:10:48.450
the place is disgustingly dirty,
it's off my list.

212
00:10:48.450 --> 00:10:52.070
Well, here's the key idea,
it's the same thing with your customers.

213
00:10:52.070 --> 00:10:54.960
Out of all the things you do with
your clients your customers,

214
00:10:54.960 --> 00:10:59.680
you know the hundreds of places you
touch them, there's three, four, maybe

215
00:10:59.680 --> 00:11:04.150
five moments of truth that make or break
your relationship with your customer.

216
00:11:04.150 --> 00:11:06.430
Your internal customer or
external customer.

217
00:11:06.430 --> 00:11:08.330
So, you've got to understand those deeply.

218
00:11:08.330 --> 00:11:12.100
You've got to find out what those are and
then I'm not a process guy,

219
00:11:12.100 --> 00:11:16.620
I don't like check list and stuff which
is weird to say to somebody in IT but

220
00:11:16.620 --> 00:11:21.780
I understand this, if you want repeatable
success, you must have process.

221
00:11:21.780 --> 00:11:24.706
>> Yeah, and I think that would
be an interesting exercise,

222
00:11:24.706 --> 00:11:27.811
to maybe sit your team down and
try to come up with what are these

223
00:11:27.811 --> 00:11:31.476
different touch points, the key
moments of truth in your own business.

224
00:11:31.476 --> 00:11:34.581
Have a great discussion and
kinda find out what everyone thinks and

225
00:11:34.581 --> 00:11:38.418
if you are all on the same page and how to
maximize those and make those better than.

226
00:11:38.418 --> 00:11:40.143
But you mentioned one more.

227
00:11:40.143 --> 00:11:41.291
You've got, three pointers?

228
00:11:41.291 --> 00:11:45.046
>> Yeah, the last one is called WOM,
which is Word of Mouth.

229
00:11:45.046 --> 00:11:47.684
And what we wanna do is do
those first two so well.

230
00:11:47.684 --> 00:11:51.349
Listen to our customers, understand them,
understanding their needs,

231
00:11:51.349 --> 00:11:55.186
define the moments of truth and which by
the way Peter I think is a great exercise

232
00:11:55.186 --> 00:11:58.060
to sit down with your team and
talk about this.

233
00:11:58.060 --> 00:12:01.490
But at the end of the day the only person
who can tell you what the moments of truth

234
00:12:01.490 --> 00:12:04.230
are is your customer.

235
00:12:04.230 --> 00:12:05.730
So you gotta go talk to them.

236
00:12:05.730 --> 00:12:09.630
Once you do those first two,
what you want to drive is number three,

237
00:12:09.630 --> 00:12:11.270
which is Word of Mouth.

238
00:12:11.270 --> 00:12:15.600
You want your client/customer to be so
excited about the work you've done, they

239
00:12:15.600 --> 00:12:18.890
tell everyone else in the organization,
they tell your boss, your manager.

240
00:12:18.890 --> 00:12:24.030
If you're going to outside customers, you
want them to be incredibly delighted, so

241
00:12:24.030 --> 00:12:26.680
that they tell everyone they
should do business with you.

242
00:12:26.680 --> 00:12:29.276
So you wanna own the voice of
the customer to understand them.

243
00:12:29.276 --> 00:12:33.858
Out of all the touch points identify
those moments of truth and deliver them

244
00:12:33.858 --> 00:12:38.366
flawlessly and if you do those two you
get out of control happy customers,

245
00:12:38.366 --> 00:12:42.270
who drive lots of word of mouth,
business or promotions.

246
00:12:42.270 --> 00:12:45.010
>> John, I think that;s a great
point thinking about the example of

247
00:12:45.010 --> 00:12:45.630
a restaurant.

248
00:12:45.630 --> 00:12:47.230
If you are the manager
of the restaurant and

249
00:12:47.230 --> 00:12:50.030
maybe there is an employee bathroom
in the back and you have no idea

250
00:12:50.030 --> 00:12:53.090
that there's this issue with the customer
bathroom until someone comes and

251
00:12:53.090 --> 00:12:57.040
tells you or you ask your customer which
is probably a little more important there.

252
00:12:57.040 --> 00:12:59.090
But, so I think we've covered
a lot of stuff in this episode.

253
00:12:59.090 --> 00:13:01.818
We've got that formula, I didn't
think there was going to be math but

00:13:01.818 --> 00:13:04.823
luckily it wasn't, and we figured out
you have to have a foosball table, and

00:13:04.823 --> 00:13:05.856
some other things there.

256
00:13:05.856 --> 00:13:10.080
But what are some of the key take
aways from this episode for you?

257
00:13:10.080 --> 00:13:14.800
>> The major things to think about here
is this is not as complex as you thought.

258
00:13:14.800 --> 00:13:19.070
There's just a handful of things
that if they're done superbly,

259
00:13:19.070 --> 00:13:21.380
will absolutely drive
success in your organization.

260
00:13:21.380 --> 00:13:25.520
The biggest one is it's all
driven by talent, which is you.

261
00:13:25.520 --> 00:13:29.750
>> Great John, well, I appreciate your
help with this and helping simplify this

00:13:29.750 --> 00:13:35.470
for us and show us how clear it can be,
it's not easy, but its also not confusing.

263
00:13:35.470 --> 00:13:37.660
So, its just figuring out that stuff.

264
00:13:37.660 --> 00:13:39.533
So, I think that that's a good point for

265
00:13:39.533 --> 00:13:42.231
us to go ahead sign off on this
episode though, we have a lot

00:13:42.231 --> 00:13:46.440
more coming on professional development in

00:13:46.440 --> 00:13:50.010
