episodes.description: Developed through direct work with leaders of top companies and a research study of 10,000 high potential employees, this video talks about the seven characteristics of a leader that people would willingly follow.
episodes.title: Leader of the Future
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.958
[SOUND]
Hello and welcome to BizPro.TV.

2
00:00:07.958 --> 00:00:09.462
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam, and

3
00:00:09.462 --> 00:00:12.390
today we're continuing our
professional development series.

4
00:00:12.390 --> 00:00:16.510
And today, in this episode, we are talking
about the leader of the future.

5
00:00:16.510 --> 00:00:18.950
Here to help us is the leader of today,
Mr. John Spence.

6
00:00:18.950 --> 00:00:20.432
John, how you doing?
>> Great, Peter, thank you.

7
00:00:20.432 --> 00:00:21.397
>> Great.
Now, John,

8
00:00:21.397 --> 00:00:24.330
what exactly are we talking
about with leader of the future?

9
00:00:24.330 --> 00:00:27.910
It sounds like some futuristic
robot movie or something?

10
00:00:27.910 --> 00:00:28.900
>> We could go there.

11
00:00:28.900 --> 00:00:31.850
There's a lot of things
happening in that area, but

12
00:00:31.850 --> 00:00:33.870
actually I've been teaching leadership for
about 20 years.

13
00:00:33.870 --> 00:00:37.150
In the last five or
six years it has started to change, and

14
00:00:37.150 --> 00:00:39.990
the requirements for
being a successful leader in the future

15
00:00:39.990 --> 00:00:42.740
are now different than they were 10 or
15 years ago.

16
00:00:42.740 --> 00:00:46.270
Did a big research study on this,
I mean, studying it for years, and

17
00:00:46.270 --> 00:00:49.880
I boiled down the pattern of what
I saw around great leadership

18
00:00:49.880 --> 00:00:52.250
to seven words that begin with C.

19
00:00:52.250 --> 00:00:54.250
The first one is character.

20
00:00:54.250 --> 00:00:56.590
Tell the truth all the time, period.

21
00:00:56.590 --> 00:00:58.130
Honesty, Integrity.

22
00:00:58.130 --> 00:01:01.040
That's actually based slightly
on another research study

23
00:01:01.040 --> 00:01:04.020
done by two of my colleagues,
Kouzes and Posner.

24
00:01:04.020 --> 00:01:08.140
They did a 30-year research study on
four continents with almost 3 million

25
00:01:08.140 --> 00:01:09.400
respondents, and

26
00:01:09.400 --> 00:01:12.720
they asked them this question,
same question I asked in my survey.

27
00:01:12.720 --> 00:01:16.190
What are the characteristics of
a leader you would willingly follow?

28
00:01:16.190 --> 00:01:18.470
They came up with six key things.

29
00:01:18.470 --> 00:01:19.900
The first one was honest.

30
00:01:19.900 --> 00:01:23.140
89% of the people worldwide,
that's 30 years,

31
00:01:23.140 --> 00:01:28.190
3 million people 89 percent had the same
first answer tell me the truth.

32
00:01:28.190 --> 00:01:31.100
The second thing they have was
forward looking, in another word for

33
00:01:31.100 --> 00:01:32.142
that would be visionary.

34
00:01:32.142 --> 00:01:35.610
That's, again, no matter where
you are in your organization,

35
00:01:35.610 --> 00:01:39.290
if you leave one person, they look to you
to set the vision for the two of you,

36
00:01:39.290 --> 00:01:41.590
so everyone has to be visionary.

37
00:01:41.590 --> 00:01:43.010
The third one was competent.

38
00:01:43.010 --> 00:01:44.270
You got to be really good at what you do,

39
00:01:44.270 --> 00:01:46.620
you actually have to
be good at Two skills.

40
00:01:46.620 --> 00:01:50.960
Your job skills, whatever those are,
your IT skills and your leadership skills.

41
00:01:50.960 --> 00:01:53.580
So, you've got to be competent
in both those areas.

42
00:01:53.580 --> 00:01:55.610
The next one was inspiring and

43
00:01:55.610 --> 00:01:58.590
that doesn't mean you've got to go ra
ra sis boom ba and be a cheerleader.

44
00:01:58.590 --> 00:02:02.660
It can be very humble, quiet, focused.

45
00:02:02.660 --> 00:02:04.690
It's inspirational passion.

46
00:02:04.690 --> 00:02:07.490
If you're not excited about
what you're doing, don't expect

47
00:02:07.490 --> 00:02:10.380
anyone else in the organization
to be excited about it either.

48
00:02:10.380 --> 00:02:11.600
Those were the four original.

49
00:02:11.600 --> 00:02:16.230
Honest, forward looking, competent and
inspiring and two more added the list.

50
00:02:16.230 --> 00:02:17.660
>> Great.
I think you made,

51
00:02:17.660 --> 00:02:21.480
well you made a lot of good points
there but one I wanted to reiterate is

52
00:02:21.480 --> 00:02:24.970
that we're not just talking about the CEO
of a company, we're talking about.

53
00:02:24.970 --> 00:02:26.160
Anyone is a leader.

54
00:02:26.160 --> 00:02:30.760
You could be down in the mailroom but
if you lead the mailroom these things

55
00:02:30.760 --> 00:02:35.980
apply to you as well so we're not just
talking about the board of directors.

56
00:02:35.980 --> 00:02:39.540
>> Yeah these are for
leader in any level in the organization.

57
00:02:39.540 --> 00:02:42.960
And frankly the truth of the matter is
everyone in every organization leads

58
00:02:42.960 --> 00:02:43.510
in some way.

59
00:02:43.510 --> 00:02:46.340
And I know that sounds cliche but
it's the truth.

60
00:02:46.340 --> 00:02:48.250
I've worked in hundreds of companies.

61
00:02:48.250 --> 00:02:50.660
And everybody plays a leadership role.

62
00:02:50.660 --> 00:02:55.060
So those first four were honest,
forward looking, competent, inspiring.

63
00:02:55.060 --> 00:02:56.500
And then in the last five years,

64
00:02:56.500 --> 00:03:00.960
thank you millennials, two more have
joined the list, fair and supportive.

65
00:03:00.960 --> 00:03:05.500
So let me take their entire research
project under my first c of character and

66
00:03:05.500 --> 00:03:06.450
summarize it.

67
00:03:06.450 --> 00:03:09.270
Here's basically what
all of those folks said.

68
00:03:09.270 --> 00:03:12.640
I want a leader who will tell me the
truth, who has a clear idea of where we're

69
00:03:12.640 --> 00:03:17.320
going, who has the skills to get us there
successfully, is excited about going with

70
00:03:17.320 --> 00:03:20.910
me, and will treat me fairly and
support me along the way.

71
00:03:20.910 --> 00:03:24.900
To me, all of that falls under
me first c of character.

72
00:03:24.900 --> 00:03:29.450
The second c is courage and
what they've got to be courageous enough,

73
00:03:29.450 --> 00:03:31.970
therefore, is to be vulnerable.

74
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:34.830
To admit, I might be the leader,
I might lead this team, this group,

75
00:03:34.830 --> 00:03:38.160
this division, this company, but
I don't have all the answers.

76
00:03:38.160 --> 00:03:39.500
I need help.

77
00:03:39.500 --> 00:03:43.780
So you have to be courageous enough to
say, I need some assistance, some help,

78
00:03:43.780 --> 00:03:44.380
some support.

79
00:03:44.380 --> 00:03:45.900
That's why I put you on my team.

80
00:03:45.900 --> 00:03:49.180
You're really good at what you do, and
I need you to help me, and not try to

81
00:03:49.180 --> 00:03:53.630
pretend like I can handle everything The
next Company we talked about a little bit

82
00:03:53.630 --> 00:03:58.460
before but the word I like to use
here is Is gonna be exceedingly got

83
00:03:58.460 --> 00:04:02.630
what you do which means committing
yourself to life long running and

84
00:04:02.630 --> 00:04:08.420
today there was no excuse for
not being really got what you do.

85
00:04:08.420 --> 00:04:14.000
There is all kind of staff in the internet
things like IT pro TV Great books.

86
00:04:14.000 --> 00:04:16.020
Lectures you can listen to.

87
00:04:16.020 --> 00:04:20.580
So, there's no excuse not to be constantly
learning, growing and getting better.

88
00:04:20.580 --> 00:04:23.040
So, competence is the next one.

89
00:04:23.040 --> 00:04:26.250
Now we're gonna move to the next
one which is communication.

90
00:04:26.250 --> 00:04:30.190
And of course, the folks said I want
a leader who's a great communicator,

91
00:04:30.190 --> 00:04:34.300
who can stand up and be inspiring and talk
about the vision and the direction and

92
00:04:34.300 --> 00:04:35.440
the strategy.

93
00:04:35.440 --> 00:04:39.310
But what they said was much more
important was getting a leader who

94
00:04:39.310 --> 00:04:41.170
asked great questions and listens.

95
00:04:42.870 --> 00:04:44.260
>> I think communication is so

96
00:04:44.260 --> 00:04:48.600
important that we actually had an entire
episode on it earlier in this series.

97
00:04:48.600 --> 00:04:51.550
So definitely go back and
watch that if you haven't yet.

98
00:04:51.550 --> 00:04:54.290
To just kind of stressing
how important that one is.

99
00:04:54.290 --> 00:04:55.380
So what's the next one?

100
00:04:55.380 --> 00:04:59.220
>> Well the next one is collaboration,
and here's what, again, and

101
00:04:59.220 --> 00:05:03.500
the way I came up with this research
is I interviewed about ten thousand

102
00:05:03.500 --> 00:05:08.332
high potential employees at top companies
around the world, and I asked the same

103
00:05:08.332 --> 00:05:12.360
question what are the characteristics
of a leader you would willingly follow.

104
00:05:12.360 --> 00:05:19.430
So right now we've got character Courage,
confidence, communication, collaboration.

105
00:05:19.430 --> 00:05:22.400
And what this says is I understand
you're my boss, my manager.

106
00:05:22.400 --> 00:05:26.090
You're the leader, but
I want you to be a partner, and

107
00:05:26.090 --> 00:05:28.690
a peer, and
a team member most of the time.

108
00:05:28.690 --> 00:05:30.670
I wanna see you roll up your sleeves,
get in there,

109
00:05:30.670 --> 00:05:34.130
get shoulder to shoulder,
do work with us And then if every now and

110
00:05:34.130 --> 00:05:37.570
then you gotta pull rank and say, do it
because I'm the manager or the leader or

111
00:05:37.570 --> 00:05:40.660
the owner or whatever it might be,
I'm fine with that.

112
00:05:40.660 --> 00:05:43.290
But if you're constantly telling me that,

113
00:05:43.290 --> 00:05:45.980
good people will leave
because they have options.

114
00:05:45.980 --> 00:05:48.480
So as a collaborator,
you wanna be a great team member.

115
00:05:48.480 --> 00:05:49.870
You get in there and do work with them.

116
00:05:49.870 --> 00:05:51.800
Understand the work they do.

117
00:05:51.800 --> 00:05:54.280
nd if you do that, every now and
then you can pull rank.

118
00:05:54.280 --> 00:05:57.640
And the next one we're gonna
look at is compassion.

119
00:05:57.640 --> 00:06:01.150
And this has really changed
a lot too around the millennials

120
00:06:01.150 --> 00:06:04.630
who say my job is important but
it's not my life.

121
00:06:04.630 --> 00:06:08.730
I'll come, I'll give you the forty, fifty
hours, whatever I'm getting paid for.

122
00:06:08.730 --> 00:06:11.830
But I've got friends,
I've got hobbies, I've got a faith,

123
00:06:11.830 --> 00:06:16.300
I've got a sport I play,
I've got a favorite brew pub I go to, and

124
00:06:16.300 --> 00:06:18.640
I'm gonna leave here and
I'm gonna have a life out of here.

125
00:06:18.640 --> 00:06:19.990
I want some balance.

126
00:06:19.990 --> 00:06:24.100
As a matter of fact, when we look at the
younger generation coming into work today,

127
00:06:24.100 --> 00:06:28.920
they've got a few different
desires than someone my age, 52.

128
00:06:28.920 --> 00:06:31.790
Has about what they look for
in a leader in a job.

129
00:06:31.790 --> 00:06:35.730
When I entered the workforce, when my
boss said, jump, it was, how high sir?

130
00:06:35.730 --> 00:06:36.390
It was all men.

131
00:06:36.390 --> 00:06:38.450
And it was all command and control.

132
00:06:38.450 --> 00:06:41.760
Today, it's exceedingly
important when you lead people,

133
00:06:41.760 --> 00:06:46.660
to lead with empathy, inclusiveness,
to help them see purpose in their work,

134
00:06:46.660 --> 00:06:50.560
so that they feel like they're doing
meaningful work They wanna work with

135
00:06:50.560 --> 00:06:54.390
cool colleagues, folks that are smart,
and bright, and talented.

136
00:06:54.390 --> 00:07:00.130
They wanna have an impact on social issues
as part of their job, and all of this goes

137
00:07:00.130 --> 00:07:04.130
to having the compassion to understand
That it's not just a job for them.

138
00:07:04.130 --> 00:07:07.700
And it's not work life integration or
work life balance.

139
00:07:07.700 --> 00:07:11.640
It's work life integration, one work
where my job is just part of who I am.

140
00:07:11.640 --> 00:07:14.630
>> So John, is this why we're calling
this leader of the future then?

141
00:07:14.630 --> 00:07:20.330
Is this kind of the change from the skills
and the qualities of a leader in the past?

142
00:07:20.330 --> 00:07:21.640
>> Yeah, if you'd looked at, Peter,

143
00:07:21.640 --> 00:07:24.430
about ten years ago,
>> The pendulum was way over as I

144
00:07:24.430 --> 00:07:26.000
mentioned command and control.

145
00:07:26.000 --> 00:07:30.410
Everything was under militaristic,
theory x, do-as-I-say-not-as-I-do style.

146
00:07:30.410 --> 00:07:33.530
People just give edicts and
said you do this or else.

147
00:07:33.530 --> 00:07:37.650
Then the pendulum swung way over for
many years to management by numbers.

148
00:07:37.650 --> 00:07:40.080
Everything was spreadsheets,
and efficiency, and

149
00:07:40.080 --> 00:07:42.670
speed, and cost
>> And

150
00:07:42.670 --> 00:07:45.210
people managed organizations
like people were cogs.

151
00:07:45.210 --> 00:07:47.190
Just things they took in, moved out.

152
00:07:47.190 --> 00:07:48.840
Lay these hundred people off, fire these,

153
00:07:48.840 --> 00:07:51.230
move that thing,
move that off to another country.

154
00:07:51.230 --> 00:07:56.050
Now the pendulum is in the middle
around empathy, teamwork, leadership.

155
00:07:56.050 --> 00:07:59.400
And there's a theory of leadership
that most of this is focused on,

156
00:07:59.400 --> 00:08:02.720
called Servant Leadership
>> By a gentleman named Greenleaf and

157
00:08:02.720 --> 00:08:05.290
this is all understand sort
of the pyramid is flip.

158
00:08:05.290 --> 00:08:09.750
And the leader is actually serve
the people that they quote and quote lead.

159
00:08:09.750 --> 00:08:13.720
And because so much work today is
based on talent and making sure you

160
00:08:13.720 --> 00:08:16.160
>> You can keep and grow the best talent

161
00:08:16.160 --> 00:08:19.870
it's essential now that leaders create
great relationships with their talents.

162
00:08:19.870 --> 00:08:23.560
And that they're empathetic and
compassionate to their needs.

163
00:08:23.560 --> 00:08:26.720
The last C which leads beautifully
into that is contribution.

164
00:08:27.770 --> 00:08:30.850
And what this means is,
after you have all those other Cs.

165
00:08:30.850 --> 00:08:34.370
You've got character, you're a great
communicator, and you're compassionate,

166
00:08:34.370 --> 00:08:35.420
and collaborator.

167
00:08:35.420 --> 00:08:36.950
And you've built this up
>> And

168
00:08:36.950 --> 00:08:40.090
you built a level of
leadership authority and

169
00:08:40.090 --> 00:08:44.630
you've got access to resources, and
you've got some influence and some power.

170
00:08:44.630 --> 00:08:47.790
That now you take all that and
you give back.

171
00:08:47.790 --> 00:08:49.030
The phrase I like to use is,

172
00:08:49.030 --> 00:08:52.780
you plant the seeds of trees
under which you may never sit.

173
00:08:52.780 --> 00:08:55.560
That you make an investment
in building other leaders

174
00:08:55.560 --> 00:08:58.840
in doing things today that would ensure
other leaders in your organization.

175
00:08:58.840 --> 00:09:02.340
That your organization Is successful,
that your team is successful.

176
00:09:02.340 --> 00:09:05.630
Some of the companies I work with
in Japan are a little bit different

177
00:09:05.630 --> 00:09:07.020
than the ones here.

178
00:09:07.020 --> 00:09:10.120
In America, because of Wall Street and
other pressure,

179
00:09:10.120 --> 00:09:12.760
we often make very short term decision.

180
00:09:12.760 --> 00:09:15.830
Gotta get this done, finish this week,
gotta make these numbers,

181
00:09:15.830 --> 00:09:17.980
gotta meet Wall Street's expectation.

182
00:09:17.980 --> 00:09:20.309
And we can be very short-sighted
in the decisions we make.

183
00:09:21.580 --> 00:09:25.020
We see this sometimes when a CEO gets
fired, and gets $100 million golden

184
00:09:25.020 --> 00:09:28.420
parachute as they leave even though
they ran the company into the ground.

185
00:09:28.420 --> 00:09:29.155
>> Be so lucky.

186
00:09:29.155 --> 00:09:34.270
>> [LAUGH] But some of the companies
in Japan I work with, the CEO does

187
00:09:34.270 --> 00:09:38.820
not get paid a penny of their bonus until
20 years after they leave the company.

188
00:09:38.820 --> 00:09:41.920
So that means they have to sit at
their desk and make 20 year decisions.

189
00:09:41.920 --> 00:09:43.960
Not what's best for
the company today but what's best for

190
00:09:43.960 --> 00:09:47.610
the company today, five years from now,
ten years from now.

191
00:09:47.610 --> 00:09:51.740
So when I look at contributions about
how can I take what I have learned as

192
00:09:51.740 --> 00:09:57.280
the leader and give it back to my people,
my community, my company and the world.

193
00:09:57.280 --> 00:09:59.060
And leave a legacy of leadership.

194
00:09:59.060 --> 00:10:01.490
>> Yeah, it's not gonna be
something that essentially

195
00:10:01.490 --> 00:10:03.180
affects the stock price tomorrow.

196
00:10:03.180 --> 00:10:04.910
But it's gonna make the company better.

197
00:10:04.910 --> 00:10:07.010
It's gonna make the employees better.

198
00:10:07.010 --> 00:10:08.570
And it's gonna work out well for everyone.

199
00:10:08.570 --> 00:10:10.360
So that's an interesting one
I hadn't thought of before.

200
00:10:10.360 --> 00:10:12.520
So any closing thoughts on this one?

201
00:10:12.520 --> 00:10:15.180
>> Well, I'd like to reiterate something
we talked about earlier that no matter

202
00:10:15.180 --> 00:10:17.830
where in the organization you are
>> you're a leader.

203
00:10:17.830 --> 00:10:20.420
And maybe you don't feel like you're
a leader in your organization, but

204
00:10:20.420 --> 00:10:23.610
you are in your family, or
your community, or your hobby.

205
00:10:23.610 --> 00:10:27.710
Whatever it might be, that all of these
skills I'm teaching are effective for

206
00:10:27.710 --> 00:10:30.660
leading in any situation at any level.

207
00:10:30.660 --> 00:10:34.370
>> And if you're effective as a leader at
one level, then hopefully you can move on

208
00:10:34.370 --> 00:10:37.340
to those further levels and
continue to advance your career.

209
00:10:37.340 --> 00:10:42.090
But John, I'm looking at the clock and I
think we're All wrapped up on this episode

210
00:10:42.090 --> 00:10:44.830
for time so we're going to go ahead and
wrap this one up but

211
00:10:44.830 --> 00:10:48.810
we have a lot more episodes on other
professional development skills coming up.

212
00:10:48.810 --> 00:10:50.860
So be sure to stay tuned for those.

213
00:10:50.860 --> 00:10:52.580
For now I'm signing off for Biz Pro TV.

214
00:10:52.580 --> 00:10:54.170
I'm Peter VanRosdam.

215
00:10:54.170 --> 00:10:54.860
>> I'm John Spence.

216
00:10:54.860 --> 00:10:56.806
>> And we'll see you next time.

217

episodes.title: How to be a Trusted Advisor
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:03.216
[SOUND] Hello, and

2
00:00:03.216 --> 00:00:07.689
welcome to BIZPRO.TV.

3
00:00:07.689 --> 00:00:09.340
I'm your host, Peter VanRysdam, and

4
00:00:09.340 --> 00:00:12.201
today we're continuing to talk
about professional development.

5
00:00:12.201 --> 00:00:16.180
And specifically in this episode, we're
talking about how to be a trusted advisor.

6
00:00:16.180 --> 00:00:20.285
And here to help us guide through that
we've got someone who I trust very much,

7
00:00:20.285 --> 00:00:21.280
Mr. John Spence.

8
00:00:21.280 --> 00:00:21.830
John, how you doing?

9
00:00:21.830 --> 00:00:22.830
>> Great, Peter, and you?

10
00:00:22.830 --> 00:00:23.652
>> I am fantastic, thank you.

11
00:00:23.652 --> 00:00:24.370
>> Excellent.

12
00:00:24.370 --> 00:00:27.060
>> So
in talking about being a trusted advisor,

13
00:00:27.060 --> 00:00:30.070
let's first take the first
part of that and trust.

14
00:00:30.070 --> 00:00:31.010
What are we talking about?

15
00:00:31.010 --> 00:00:33.899
How do we build trust
within our organization?

16
00:00:33.899 --> 00:00:37.982
>> Trust can be an ambiguous term,
so I created my own definition,

17
00:00:37.982 --> 00:00:40.580
which I call the four Cs of trust.

18
00:00:40.580 --> 00:00:43.510
And that is you must
consistently communicate

19
00:00:43.510 --> 00:00:45.540
that you're competent and you care.

20
00:00:45.540 --> 00:00:48.320
Consistently communicate you're competent,
you care.

21
00:00:48.320 --> 00:00:51.010
Let's look at how I put those
together in four levels of trust.

22
00:00:52.160 --> 00:00:56.710
The lowest level, or level one,
is high competence, low concern.

23
00:00:56.710 --> 00:01:00.326
I'm extremely good at what I do,
very talented, genius, brilliant, but

24
00:01:00.326 --> 00:01:00.955
I'm an ass.

25
00:01:00.955 --> 00:01:03.960
[LAUGH] We don't trust people like that.

26
00:01:03.960 --> 00:01:05.730
The word I use is respect.

27
00:01:05.730 --> 00:01:09.240
I respect their skill,
their talent, their expertise, but

28
00:01:09.240 --> 00:01:12.530
I do not trust them because I know
they don't care about me at all.

29
00:01:12.530 --> 00:01:14.930
The next level is low confidence,
low concern.

30
00:01:14.930 --> 00:01:18.685
I'm incompetent and I don't care, yeah,
I work at the post office [LAUGH].

31
00:01:18.685 --> 00:01:21.704
Well, I only say that because I was
teaching some folks from the post office,

32
00:01:21.704 --> 00:01:23.290
and one of them said, hey, that's us.

33
00:01:23.290 --> 00:01:24.820
I go, that's not funny, and
he goes, no, that's us.

34
00:01:24.820 --> 00:01:26.178
We're incompetent, we don't care.

35
00:01:26.178 --> 00:01:27.991
I guess it's just that one guy, I hope.

36
00:01:27.991 --> 00:01:31.430
But low competence,
low concern, that's distrust.

37
00:01:31.430 --> 00:01:34.860
Someone who's not smart,
doesn't have skills, and

38
00:01:34.860 --> 00:01:37.250
doesn't care about you, doesn't work.

39
00:01:37.250 --> 00:01:40.530
The next one is high concern,
but low competence.

40
00:01:40.530 --> 00:01:42.650
Really nice person, incredibly friendly,

41
00:01:42.650 --> 00:01:45.800
love to have them over to the house
on a weekend for barbecue, or

42
00:01:45.800 --> 00:01:49.430
go play golf together, but
unfortunately, they're incompetent.

43
00:01:49.430 --> 00:01:51.715
And typically, when you have
someone like that on your team,

44
00:01:51.715 --> 00:01:53.800
you're the one that has
to do all their work.

45
00:01:53.800 --> 00:01:55.610
So the word I use there is affection.

46
00:01:55.610 --> 00:01:58.830
I like them, they're kind, they're sweet.

47
00:01:58.830 --> 00:02:02.811
And we have a saying for this South, as
you will know, Peter, he's trying so hard,

48
00:02:02.811 --> 00:02:04.453
bless his heart, he's an idiot.

49
00:02:04.453 --> 00:02:05.680
[LAUGH]
>> Here in the South.

50
00:02:05.680 --> 00:02:10.300
>> Here in the South, but so
that's high concern, but low competence.

51
00:02:10.300 --> 00:02:13.300
So when we're looking at trying to
build trust in an organization,

52
00:02:13.300 --> 00:02:18.400
trust as an individual,
you want high competence, high concern.

53
00:02:18.400 --> 00:02:21.070
You must consistently communicate
you're competent, you care.

54
00:02:21.070 --> 00:02:25.710
High competence, high concern, and
I can boil that all down to one phrase.

55
00:02:25.710 --> 00:02:29.100
I'm good at what I do, and
I do it because I care about you.

56
00:02:29.100 --> 00:02:32.870
Problem with this is it can take a long
time to build up trust like that,

57
00:02:32.870 --> 00:02:34.210
weeks, months, or years.

58
00:02:34.210 --> 00:02:36.270
And you can lose it in just a few seconds.

59
00:02:36.270 --> 00:02:37.519
>> Sure, I've done that before, I'm sure.

60
00:02:37.519 --> 00:02:40.372
>> [LAUGH]
>> So now that we understand trust,

61
00:02:40.372 --> 00:02:42.938
how do we take that into
this trusted advisor role?

62
00:02:42.938 --> 00:02:47.700
>> Okay, I'm gonna really push this to
a high level because I have fairly high

63
00:02:47.700 --> 00:02:50.690
expectations around this
idea of trusted advisor.

64
00:02:50.690 --> 00:02:55.810
Because I think it's one of the key things
that differentiates a good employee

65
00:02:55.810 --> 00:02:59.910
from a great employer, salesperson, or
IT technician, whatever it might be.

66
00:02:59.910 --> 00:03:04.780
And so the first challenge is, what do you
believe it would take to be first class?

67
00:03:04.780 --> 00:03:09.140
What do you truly think to do your
job the best in the world would do?

68
00:03:09.140 --> 00:03:10.740
I'll give a very quick example.

69
00:03:10.740 --> 00:03:13.805
When I decided I'd go into this field,
being a consultant,

70
00:03:13.805 --> 00:03:16.943
a professional speaker trainer,
I looked around the world.

71
00:03:16.943 --> 00:03:20.008
And at that time, Tom Peters,
who wrote In Search of Excellence,

72
00:03:20.008 --> 00:03:22.800
a couple other books,
was number one in the world.

73
00:03:22.800 --> 00:03:23.780
So what I did is,

74
00:03:23.780 --> 00:03:27.360
I wrote out a check list of everything
Tom Peters had done to become number one.

75
00:03:27.360 --> 00:03:28.330
Where did he work?

76
00:03:28.330 --> 00:03:29.370
What was his expertise?

77
00:03:29.370 --> 00:03:30.045
Did he write books?

78
00:03:30.045 --> 00:03:30.810
Where did he travel?

79
00:03:30.810 --> 00:03:31.970
Everything.

80
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:33.860
I created that list, and
then I got up every day and

81
00:03:33.860 --> 00:03:35.470
started checking stuff off that list.

82
00:03:35.470 --> 00:03:38.410
And about four years ago,
I actually got named with him as

83
00:03:38.410 --> 00:03:42.180
one of the top 100 professional leadership
speakers in the world, so I caught him.

84
00:03:42.180 --> 00:03:43.570
And I don't say that to impress you,

85
00:03:43.570 --> 00:03:47.650
but to let you know that,
that's how easy it really is.

86
00:03:47.650 --> 00:03:50.610
What would it take to be world class,
create a very clear and

87
00:03:50.610 --> 00:03:54.490
specific checklist, then get up every day
and just start checking stuff off that.

88
00:03:54.490 --> 00:03:57.690
That's the first step to
becoming a trusted advisor.

89
00:03:57.690 --> 00:04:00.170
Now, I also have a couple of levels here

90
00:04:00.170 --> 00:04:03.580
of what it takes to build yourself
up to being a trusted advisor.

91
00:04:03.580 --> 00:04:07.614
At the lowest level,
it's just good solid general business,

92
00:04:07.614 --> 00:04:11.585
economic global information,
are you reading, studying?

93
00:04:11.585 --> 00:04:13.105
Not to be an expert on it, but so

94
00:04:13.105 --> 00:04:16.620
that you can carry on a conversation
with your customer, your client.

95
00:04:16.620 --> 00:04:21.111
You see how other things impact your
business, your employer, the economy,

96
00:04:21.111 --> 00:04:23.777
just good solid general
business knowledge.

97
00:04:23.777 --> 00:04:29.313
Level two is you must be an expert at your
job, and I do not use that word lightly.

98
00:04:29.313 --> 00:04:33.910
When I say expert, I mean, you've gotta
be really, really good at what you do.

99
00:04:33.910 --> 00:04:35.760
Constantly learning, studying,

100
00:04:35.760 --> 00:04:40.620
improving, doing everything you can
to be at the very top of your game.

101
00:04:40.620 --> 00:04:43.970
Next, you've gotta
understand your customer.

102
00:04:43.970 --> 00:04:44.870
What do they want?

103
00:04:44.870 --> 00:04:46.320
What's important to them?

104
00:04:46.320 --> 00:04:47.740
What needs do they have?

105
00:04:47.740 --> 00:04:49.810
What keeps them up at night?

106
00:04:49.810 --> 00:04:52.040
What are they concerned about
around their IT issues?

107
00:04:52.040 --> 00:04:55.560
So you gotta really understand
your customer deeply.

108
00:04:55.560 --> 00:04:58.750
Once you've got those levels,
I've got good general business knowledge,

109
00:04:58.750 --> 00:05:00.340
good business acumen.

110
00:05:00.340 --> 00:05:03.744
I'm world class at my job,
truly great at it.

111
00:05:03.744 --> 00:05:06.870
I understand the people that
I serve extremely well.

112
00:05:06.870 --> 00:05:10.280
That allows you to get to the highest
level, which is the trusted advisor,

113
00:05:10.280 --> 00:05:11.560
a partner, and a peer.

114
00:05:11.560 --> 00:05:15.700
Where you bring solutions to problems
they didn't even know they had yet.

115
00:05:15.700 --> 00:05:19.640
That you're making recommendations, or
I like to say, you see around the corner.

116
00:05:19.640 --> 00:05:25.220
That you help them by understanding
their workload, what they're doing so

117
00:05:25.220 --> 00:05:29.410
well that you can figure out how to
fix things before they go wrong.

118
00:05:29.410 --> 00:05:32.826
>> Now John, a lot of what we've been
talking about leading up to this

119
00:05:32.826 --> 00:05:37.098
in other episodes has been leadership and
how these skills can help you as a leader.

120
00:05:37.098 --> 00:05:40.989
This, to me, sounds like something that,
doesn't matter if you're a leader or not,

121
00:05:40.989 --> 00:05:43.514
but being a trusted advisor
can be something to strive for

122
00:05:43.514 --> 00:05:44.948
in any position of the company.

123
00:05:44.948 --> 00:05:45.531
Is that true?

124
00:05:45.531 --> 00:05:49.347
>> Yeah, to me, this is something that
underlines being a great employee, and

125
00:05:49.347 --> 00:05:52.400
this is an investment in you and
your career.

126
00:05:52.400 --> 00:05:58.220
Only about 5 to 10% of people ever
get to the level of trusted advisor.

127
00:05:58.220 --> 00:06:01.620
It's not hard to do, but it takes a lot
of work, and it takes a lot of homework.

128
00:06:02.830 --> 00:06:06.910
There's a three letter acronym I use
to help people think about this.

129
00:06:06.910 --> 00:06:07.710
Years ago,

130
00:06:07.710 --> 00:06:12.750
I was asked by a large company to do
a speech on the essence of excellence.

131
00:06:12.750 --> 00:06:17.410
And I got it down to three key
letters to be truly excellent, FDA.

132
00:06:17.410 --> 00:06:21.210
The first one is focus,
you've gotta be extremely focused

133
00:06:21.210 --> 00:06:24.520
on your philosophy of excellence,
on that checklist we just talked about.

134
00:06:24.520 --> 00:06:28.860
On all the levels of becoming a trusted
advisor, especially that competence level.

135
00:06:28.860 --> 00:06:32.460
You gotta be intensely focused on that,
looking at it everyday.

136
00:06:32.460 --> 00:06:34.035
The D stands for discipline.

137
00:06:34.035 --> 00:06:36.160
You have to have the discipline
to actually do it.

138
00:06:36.160 --> 00:06:38.750
Not just put it on a notepad,
not just talk about it,

139
00:06:38.750 --> 00:06:43.200
not just make it a goal, but actually
get up everyday and live that list,

140
00:06:43.200 --> 00:06:45.350
live what it takes to
be a trusted advisor.

141
00:06:45.350 --> 00:06:47.260
And then the A stands for action.

142
00:06:47.260 --> 00:06:50.700
The amount of action you apply determines
the amount of results you get.

143
00:06:50.700 --> 00:06:53.520
Little bit of focus, not quite
sure how to be a trusted advisor,

144
00:06:53.520 --> 00:06:56.650
how to take your career to the next level,
a little bit of discipline.

145
00:06:56.650 --> 00:07:00.050
I know that I don't do it every day,
or a little bit of action.

146
00:07:00.050 --> 00:07:04.750
The outcome is mediocrity, and once you
start accepting mediocrity in your life,

147
00:07:04.750 --> 00:07:07.300
you become a magnet for
mediocrity in your life.

148
00:07:07.300 --> 00:07:11.570
So those are how I look at building up
this level of being a trusted advisor.

149
00:07:11.570 --> 00:07:13.930
>> Well I'll never look at
the FDA the same way now.

150
00:07:13.930 --> 00:07:15.948
[LAUGH] So are there any other tips or

151
00:07:15.948 --> 00:07:19.560
steps that we need to take
to be that trusted advisor?

152
00:07:19.560 --> 00:07:22.020
>> Yeah, there's two more
things I'd like to bring up.

153
00:07:22.020 --> 00:07:25.920
One was a big aha moment for
me when I was early in my career.

154
00:07:25.920 --> 00:07:28.840
Because sometimes I felt like
it was me versus my boss or

155
00:07:28.840 --> 00:07:30.260
me versus one of the other departments.

156
00:07:30.260 --> 00:07:33.110
Or when I was in sales,
it was me versus the customer, and

157
00:07:33.110 --> 00:07:37.250
then I realized we all want the same
thing, the exact right solution.

158
00:07:38.330 --> 00:07:42.260
If I bring in a solution that doesn't
work and I get it done quickly and

159
00:07:42.260 --> 00:07:44.660
I think it's fantastic and
I deliver it and I'm proud of it, but

160
00:07:44.660 --> 00:07:46.890
it doesn't work for
the customer, it doesn't work.

161
00:07:46.890 --> 00:07:48.700
So, we're both on the same team.

162
00:07:48.700 --> 00:07:50.990
It's not me versus them arm wrestling.

163
00:07:50.990 --> 00:07:55.380
It's us working together as a team,
as partners, to try to get the exact

164
00:07:55.380 --> 00:08:00.780
right solution that's best for both of us,
which is what a true trusted advisor does.

165
00:08:00.780 --> 00:08:01.620
One of the ways you do that,

166
00:08:01.620 --> 00:08:05.820
which is my second point, is to be
really good at managing expectations.

167
00:08:05.820 --> 00:08:10.620
I think a lot of problems happen when we
have poor communication, we don't clarify

168
00:08:10.620 --> 00:08:14.950
the expectations, and our client or
customer has expectations way up here.

169
00:08:14.950 --> 00:08:15.800
And we deliver this and

170
00:08:15.800 --> 00:08:18.770
think it's awesome, and
they still think that we failed.

171
00:08:18.770 --> 00:08:22.880
So if you can manage those expectations
appropriately through good communications,

172
00:08:22.880 --> 00:08:27.550
understanding your client, doing all that,
then you can set the expectations here.

173
00:08:27.550 --> 00:08:29.030
Where you know you can always meet or

174
00:08:29.030 --> 00:08:33.830
exceed them consistently, which again,
positions you as a trusted advisor.

175
00:08:33.830 --> 00:08:37.500
>> Okay, so let's say now that you
didn't watch our earlier episode about

176
00:08:37.500 --> 00:08:38.690
listening skills.

177
00:08:38.690 --> 00:08:40.490
Can you give us a quick recap,

178
00:08:40.490 --> 00:08:45.850
kind of going back to how to build trust
and then how to be a trusted advisor?

179
00:08:45.850 --> 00:08:47.360
>> We just talked with trust is,

180
00:08:47.360 --> 00:08:50.040
the four Cs, consistently communicate
you're competent, you care.

181
00:08:50.040 --> 00:08:54.130
One of the most important ways you do
that is asking excellent questions.

182
00:08:54.130 --> 00:08:57.060
And the best way to think of how
to ask an excellent question is,

183
00:08:57.060 --> 00:08:59.020
think of the answer you wanna get.

184
00:08:59.020 --> 00:09:00.320
I'm not being manipulative here.

185
00:09:00.320 --> 00:09:01.970
I'm saying, what information do you need?

186
00:09:01.970 --> 00:09:03.780
What data do you have to collect?

187
00:09:03.780 --> 00:09:05.440
What is the answer I need?

188
00:09:05.440 --> 00:09:10.050
Then back up and formulate a question
that will get the person to say that.

189
00:09:10.050 --> 00:09:14.680
One of the tricks that I always use is I
want to get the other person to tell me

190
00:09:14.680 --> 00:09:16.170
what I want them to hear.

191
00:09:16.170 --> 00:09:19.590
Instead of me saying, you need this,
I wanna ask them enough questions,

192
00:09:19.590 --> 00:09:20.900
they say, I really need this.

193
00:09:20.900 --> 00:09:23.380
You go, great, I can deliver that for you.

194
00:09:23.380 --> 00:09:26.360
And then the other thing around
that is to be an intense listener.

195
00:09:26.360 --> 00:09:29.330
And that's all about summarizing,
paraphrasing,

196
00:09:29.330 --> 00:09:31.030
repeating in your head over and
over again.

197
00:09:31.030 --> 00:09:34.050
Being totally focused on
the person that's in front of you,

198
00:09:34.050 --> 00:09:37.890
giving you this extremely important
information, writing good notes.

199
00:09:37.890 --> 00:09:41.410
So that they know, again as a trusted
advisor, you care about them.

200
00:09:41.410 --> 00:09:44.110
You've asked these great questions,
you're focused on their needs, and

201
00:09:44.110 --> 00:09:45.790
you're going to remember it.

202
00:09:45.790 --> 00:09:48.086
Because you took the time
to take careful notes,

203
00:09:48.086 --> 00:09:51.054
read them back to them,
summarized them, paraphrased them,

204
00:09:51.054 --> 00:09:53.861
and clearly demonstrated that
you're good at what you do.

205
00:09:53.861 --> 00:09:55.663
And you do it because you care about them.

206
00:09:55.663 --> 00:09:57.967
>> Well,
I think this is a great goal to set for

207
00:09:57.967 --> 00:10:00.920
yourself to become a trusted
advisor in your company.

208
00:10:00.920 --> 00:10:04.560
It helps you as an employee, helps you as
a leader, and it's something that you can

209
00:10:04.560 --> 00:10:07.440
kinda put into action right away,
so I think that's fantastic.

210
00:10:07.440 --> 00:10:10.450
But, John, it looks like we're about
out of time for this episode, so

211
00:10:10.450 --> 00:10:12.140
any closing thoughts?

212
00:10:12.140 --> 00:10:13.920
>> Just the dedication
of lifelong learning.

213
00:10:13.920 --> 00:10:17.980
You'll never be a trusted advisor
unless you're insanely competent, so,

214
00:10:17.980 --> 00:10:20.750
you've gotta continue to invest
in yourself and in your career.

215
00:10:20.750 --> 00:10:23.750
>> Great, great ideas,
great suggestions there.

216
00:10:23.750 --> 00:10:27.880
So that's gonna do it for us for
this episode on BIZPRO.TV, but

217
00:10:27.880 --> 00:10:29.630
we've got a lot more great content.

218
00:10:29.630 --> 00:10:31.390
So make sure to check that out.

219
00:10:31.390 --> 00:10:34.170
But signing off for now,
I've been your host, Peter VanRysdam.

220
00:10:34.170 --> 00:10:34.930
>> I'm John Spence.

221
00:10:34.930 --> 00:10:36.851
>> And we'll see you next time.

222
00:10:36.851 --> 00:10:46.281

episodes.description: Based in part on ideas from the Harvard Negotiations Program, this session outlines six essential elements for being a highly successful negotiator and makes them simple to understand and apply.
episodes.title: The Fundamentals of Negotiation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:05.811 --> 00:00:07.432
Hello and welcome to BizProTV.

2
00:00:07.432 --> 00:00:09.050
I'm your host Peter VanRsydam and

3
00:00:09.050 --> 00:00:12.680
today we're continuing our series
about professional development.

4
00:00:12.680 --> 00:00:15.671
And specifically in this episode we're
getting into some of the fun stuff,

5
00:00:15.671 --> 00:00:17.084
the fundamentals of negotiation.

6
00:00:17.084 --> 00:00:21.200
And here to help us with that is a master
negotiator, our expert, John Spence.

7
00:00:21.200 --> 00:00:21.950
John, how are you doing?

8
00:00:21.950 --> 00:00:22.920
>> Great, Peter, how are you?

9
00:00:22.920 --> 00:00:24.140
>> I am well, thank you.

10
00:00:24.140 --> 00:00:26.510
So, I'd like to talk about this.

11
00:00:26.510 --> 00:00:30.160
We're thinking about negotiation
normally in a sales process,

12
00:00:30.160 --> 00:00:35.510
but is this just for sales or
is this negotiation across the business?

13
00:00:35.510 --> 00:00:37.361
>> No.
Pretty much whatever role you play in

14
00:00:37.361 --> 00:00:40.705
a business, there's going to be
times when you have to negotiate,

15
00:00:40.705 --> 00:00:44.051
timelines on projects, resources,
getting people on your team,

16
00:00:44.051 --> 00:00:47.300
maybe need some flex time, and
you can't turn things in on time.

17
00:00:48.370 --> 00:00:51.780
So there's always negotiations
inside of an organization, and

18
00:00:51.780 --> 00:00:56.300
use some of the same elements as what you
might do for a sales negotiation, but

19
00:00:56.300 --> 00:00:57.870
they're a little bit different.

20
00:00:57.870 --> 00:01:01.960
>> All right, so I'm assuming based on our
previous episodes that you either have

21
00:01:01.960 --> 00:01:06.990
an acronym, or you have broken this
down into the six major points.

22
00:01:06.990 --> 00:01:08.610
So what do you got for us this time?

23
00:01:08.610 --> 00:01:10.805
>> [LAUGH] I have the five
fundamentals of negotiation.

24
00:01:10.805 --> 00:01:11.530
>> Five.

25
00:01:11.530 --> 00:01:13.570
>> Yeah, I have gotta have a number on it.

26
00:01:13.570 --> 00:01:18.095
And what I've done is I've taken several
large courses, read a bunch of books,

27
00:01:18.095 --> 00:01:22.303
negotiated the largest deal I've
ever negotiated was $3.2 billion.

28
00:01:22.303 --> 00:01:25.631
A lot of experience, but I looked at
it and said, out of all those things,

29
00:01:25.631 --> 00:01:28.369
what are the three, four,
five and it turned out to be five,

30
00:01:28.369 --> 00:01:32.220
key things that if you do these well
it's sort of the AD-20 principle.

31
00:01:32.220 --> 00:01:35.900
So, here are the five things you
have to do to be a great negotiator.

32
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:39.050
Number one, be exceedingly well prepared,

33
00:01:39.050 --> 00:01:42.150
do you homework,
write out notes, have a plan for

34
00:01:42.150 --> 00:01:46.380
the negotiation, make sure you collect
lots of data, come to the negotiation.

35
00:01:46.380 --> 00:01:48.620
And it depends on the size of negotiation.

36
00:01:48.620 --> 00:01:52.160
If I'm walking down the hallway to ask,
if I can turn something in it 4:00

37
00:01:52.160 --> 00:01:56.380
o'clock this afternoon instead of at noon,
I don't need to do a lot of prep.

38
00:01:56.380 --> 00:02:00.490
If I'm going to negotiate
a major project standards for

39
00:02:00.490 --> 00:02:03.860
what people want in their work,
all kinds of things like that

40
00:02:03.860 --> 00:02:06.970
that are much more detailed,
really gotta do a lot of homework.

41
00:02:06.970 --> 00:02:10.610
So step one is be
exceedingly well prepared.

42
00:02:10.610 --> 00:02:12.390
>> Tom can you, it's always helpful for

43
00:02:12.390 --> 00:02:14.950
me when you have kind of
an example to go off of.

44
00:02:14.950 --> 00:02:16.690
So let's put kind of
a story around this and

45
00:02:16.690 --> 00:02:21.210
I think one negotiation that everybody
is pretty used to is buying a car.

46
00:02:21.210 --> 00:02:23.660
That's something if you've
never been in business before,

47
00:02:23.660 --> 00:02:24.630
you've probably done that.

48
00:02:24.630 --> 00:02:27.920
So being prepared in
that case would be what?

49
00:02:27.920 --> 00:02:31.970
Going and doing your research online,
checking out prices at competitors,

50
00:02:31.970 --> 00:02:32.780
things like that.

51
00:02:32.780 --> 00:02:33.550
>> Exactly.

52
00:02:33.550 --> 00:02:36.663
You go to CarFax,
you'd look online at several other.

53
00:02:36.663 --> 00:02:41.470
You pick a type of car you want and I'd
look at four or five dealers in the area.

54
00:02:41.470 --> 00:02:45.920
I'd look at CarFax,
I would look at motor trends to get

55
00:02:45.920 --> 00:02:49.620
all the feedback I could and
create a file.

56
00:02:49.620 --> 00:02:52.350
For two reasons, a,
to show you have done your homework.

57
00:02:52.350 --> 00:02:55.370
But number two is when you
walk into the dealership,

58
00:02:55.370 --> 00:02:57.440
they can see that you're
very well prepared.

59
00:02:57.440 --> 00:03:00.180
You probably know as much or
more about the car and

60
00:03:00.180 --> 00:03:02.390
their competitors than they do.

61
00:03:02.390 --> 00:03:05.750
So that shows them a very
high level of preparation.

62
00:03:05.750 --> 00:03:09.530
Same thing works internally when
you're negotiating with other people.

63
00:03:09.530 --> 00:03:15.750
The second thing about negotiations or
number two is having lots of ways to win.

64
00:03:15.750 --> 00:03:18.050
And it's one of my favorite phrases and

65
00:03:18.050 --> 00:03:21.350
I think it's the two most
fundamental things for negotiation.

66
00:03:21.350 --> 00:03:25.874
Typically, whose having the best prepared
to win and has most ways to win, wins.

67
00:03:25.874 --> 00:03:29.150
So let us go back to our car example.

68
00:03:29.150 --> 00:03:31.190
If I walk onto the lot and let me see,

69
00:03:31.190 --> 00:03:35.220
I'll use an Eddie Bauer Ford Explorer,
cuz I used to own one of those.

70
00:03:35.220 --> 00:03:39.830
If I walk on the Ford lot and I say,
I'd like an Eddie Bauer Ford Explorer.

71
00:03:39.830 --> 00:03:44.380
I'd like it in green, I want the leather
interior, I need the tow package,

72
00:03:44.380 --> 00:03:49.500
I want the upgraded stereo,
I wanna make sure it has tinted windows,

73
00:03:49.500 --> 00:03:52.790
and it's got heated seats and
I go through all these things.

74
00:03:52.790 --> 00:03:56.297
There's probably only one on
the lot that meets my criteria, and

75
00:03:56.297 --> 00:03:58.479
now the car dealer has all the leverage.

76
00:03:58.479 --> 00:04:03.350
I only have one way to win, and
they hold the one thing that I wanna win.

77
00:04:03.350 --> 00:04:05.280
So I'm at a real disadvantage.

78
00:04:05.280 --> 00:04:09.080
But if I walked on the car lot and said
I'm interested in buying a truck today.

79
00:04:09.080 --> 00:04:11.330
It doesn't even have to be a Ford.

80
00:04:11.330 --> 00:04:14.350
I'd like a green, a brown,
something like that.

81
00:04:14.350 --> 00:04:16.930
Just not yellow or white,
not crazy about yellow or white.

82
00:04:16.930 --> 00:04:18.940
And if I have to I can go with white.

83
00:04:18.940 --> 00:04:21.900
I'd like something with a tow package but
I can have it put on.

84
00:04:21.900 --> 00:04:24.990
Moon roof would be nice, not necessary.

85
00:04:24.990 --> 00:04:27.800
Gotta have air conditioning,
that's for sure, live in Florida.

86
00:04:27.800 --> 00:04:32.690
It would be great if it had an upgraded
stereo but it's not that big of a deal.

87
00:04:32.690 --> 00:04:37.510
Now out of the 500 cars on the parking
lot or trucks there's probably a dozen or

88
00:04:37.510 --> 00:04:39.120
so that meet my criteria.

89
00:04:39.120 --> 00:04:42.460
So if they show me one and
it isn't exactly what I want,

90
00:04:42.460 --> 00:04:44.620
I can try to negotiate down on price.

91
00:04:44.620 --> 00:04:47.860
If they won't hit me there, I'll just
go fine, let's look at another one.

92
00:04:47.860 --> 00:04:50.076
So I have multiple ways to win.

93
00:04:50.076 --> 00:04:54.586
And the way this now goes to
negotiating side of a business is,

94
00:04:54.586 --> 00:04:58.660
I wanna win a,
this is my perfect outcome would be a, but

95
00:04:58.660 --> 00:05:04.620
b would be acceptable too, and
c would work, and I'd even go for d.

96
00:05:04.620 --> 00:05:08.536
But I can take part of a and
part of d and put together for a two.

97
00:05:08.536 --> 00:05:11.564
And now you've got all
this ways to switch and

98
00:05:11.564 --> 00:05:16.358
come up with deals that you're happy
with and other side is happy with.

99
00:05:16.358 --> 00:05:18.201
So again your gotta be extremely
well prepared and have lots and

100
00:05:18.201 --> 00:05:18.805
lots of ways to win.

101
00:05:18.805 --> 00:05:22.311
>> Yes, as I say don't put all your
eggs in one basket giving yourself

102
00:05:22.311 --> 00:05:26.819
multiple outcomes, then you're gonna find
an option that's gonna work for you, so

103
00:05:26.819 --> 00:05:27.865
that makes sense.

104
00:05:27.865 --> 00:05:30.600
So that was number two,
so what's number three?

105
00:05:30.600 --> 00:05:32.950
>> Number three is I call
think I call the continuum.

106
00:05:32.950 --> 00:05:35.870
And this is especially important for
internal negotiations.

107
00:05:36.980 --> 00:05:40.270
When you begin a negotiation you
have to decide both for yourself and

108
00:05:40.270 --> 00:05:43.700
the other person,
are they your negotiating partner?

109
00:05:43.700 --> 00:05:44.928
Are they negotiating counterpart?

110
00:05:44.928 --> 00:05:48.050
Or are they your negotiating opponent?

111
00:05:48.050 --> 00:05:51.640
And the way you find out is you ask
questions and share information.

112
00:05:51.640 --> 00:05:54.940
If they're your negotiating partner,
they're gonna answer your questions.

113
00:05:54.940 --> 00:05:55.487
They're gonna give you data.

114
00:05:55.487 --> 00:05:57.710
You're gonna have a conversation.

115
00:05:57.710 --> 00:05:59.740
They're gonna do everything
they can to help you.

116
00:05:59.740 --> 00:06:02.170
It's truly gonna be aimed at win-win.

117
00:06:02.170 --> 00:06:03.811
That's your negotiating partner.

118
00:06:03.811 --> 00:06:08.750
You're negotiating counterpart is polite,
but not overly helpful.

119
00:06:08.750 --> 00:06:12.480
They're not aggressive, but they're
not giving you everything you want.

120
00:06:12.480 --> 00:06:14.880
They're just saying hey,
let's get a good deal.

121
00:06:14.880 --> 00:06:18.492
I'm not particularly concerned
if you're not very happy.

122
00:06:18.492 --> 00:06:21.350
I wanna win, but I don't need you to lose.

123
00:06:21.350 --> 00:06:25.320
I'm okay if we,
it's just we walk away feeling all right.

124
00:06:25.320 --> 00:06:29.740
And then if they're your negotiating
opponent, that's lose win.

125
00:06:29.740 --> 00:06:31.460
They want you to lose and they win.

126
00:06:31.460 --> 00:06:34.002
They're not gonna give you information,
you ask questions.

127
00:06:34.002 --> 00:06:37.220
One of the best ways is to ask
questions you know the answer to and

128
00:06:37.220 --> 00:06:40.317
see if they tell you the truth,
and here's the idea around,

129
00:06:40.317 --> 00:06:42.720
I've got two big ideas around this.

130
00:06:42.720 --> 00:06:47.110
Is as you enter the negotiation it's
my opinion at least that you should

131
00:06:47.110 --> 00:06:51.190
assume that the other person
is your negotiating partner.

132
00:06:51.190 --> 00:06:54.920
And share information with them
be open and as soon as they

133
00:06:54.920 --> 00:06:58.980
give you a red flag they refuse to answer
a question they refuse to give you data.

134
00:06:58.980 --> 00:07:01.130
They give you data that
you know is not correct,

135
00:07:01.130 --> 00:07:06.050
then they jump up on the continuum not
my partner could be my counter part.

136
00:07:06.050 --> 00:07:07.680
Then you ask them a few more questions.

137
00:07:07.680 --> 00:07:08.291
You negotiate for awhile.

138
00:07:08.291 --> 00:07:10.330
You see their position.

139
00:07:10.330 --> 00:07:12.160
And now they're getting more aggressive.

140
00:07:12.160 --> 00:07:13.710
And they're refusing to give you data.

141
00:07:13.710 --> 00:07:16.680
And they're asking for things that
you really don't wanna give them.

142
00:07:16.680 --> 00:07:18.937
Now you skip it up into
negotiating opponent.

143
00:07:18.937 --> 00:07:21.260
But here's what most people do.

144
00:07:21.260 --> 00:07:24.040
They walk in thinking
we're against each other.

145
00:07:24.040 --> 00:07:26.610
And they start at opponent, opponent and

146
00:07:26.610 --> 00:07:31.160
it's very hard to get to win-win when
both of you are being aggressive or

147
00:07:31.160 --> 00:07:34.760
not sharing information or trying to
make sure that you get the better deal.

148
00:07:34.760 --> 00:07:40.220
Part two of that is you have to
understand the relationship.

149
00:07:40.220 --> 00:07:41.760
I'll give you an example on this one.

150
00:07:41.760 --> 00:07:45.290
I had a friend years ago
that wanted to buy a car.

151
00:07:45.290 --> 00:07:46.780
His wife had just had another baby.

152
00:07:46.780 --> 00:07:47.893
They needed a big Suburban.

153
00:07:47.893 --> 00:07:52.710
So we went into the car dealership,
and he found the car he wanted,

154
00:07:52.710 --> 00:07:59.347
it was about $23,000 used Suburban,
and he negotiated it down to $20,005.

155
00:07:59.347 --> 00:08:07.050
And they get to the table, and the
salesperson says, all right, it's $20,005.

156
00:08:07.050 --> 00:08:09.050
And my friend says no,
I'm just gonna pay $20,000.

157
00:08:09.050 --> 00:08:11.850
I wanna write a check for 2-0-0-0-0.

158
00:08:11.850 --> 00:08:13.182
I don't want the $5.

159
00:08:13.182 --> 00:08:15.780
And the salesperson goes no,
you're gonna give me the $5.

160
00:08:15.780 --> 00:08:17.610
And you can see where this was going.

161
00:08:17.610 --> 00:08:18.870
Back and forth, back and forth.

162
00:08:18.870 --> 00:08:23.350
Finally the salesperson gets so
exasperated he reaches into his pocket,

163
00:08:23.350 --> 00:08:27.970
pulls out $5, throws it on the table and
says, there, I'll pay the $5.

164
00:08:27.970 --> 00:08:30.880
But I hope you never have to
bring it back for service.

165
00:08:30.880 --> 00:08:33.747
So if you plan to never
see this person again,

166
00:08:33.747 --> 00:08:36.243
you can negotiate very aggressively.

167
00:08:36.243 --> 00:08:38.846
But internal negotiations,
most of the time,

168
00:08:38.846 --> 00:08:43.810
you gotta see them in the hallway later,
you gotta work on other projects together.

169
00:08:43.810 --> 00:08:50.550
So having a competitive opponent style of
negotiation internally is not a good idea.

170
00:08:50.550 --> 00:08:52.660
>> So it sounds like if you walk
into the negotiating room and

171
00:08:52.660 --> 00:08:54.440
you draw a line in the sand
right at the beginning.

172
00:08:54.440 --> 00:08:57.930
Not only are you setting that kinda
adversarial relationship, but

173
00:08:57.930 --> 00:08:59.630
you're going against number two.

174
00:08:59.630 --> 00:09:02.620
You're saying here's my one outcome
that I'm gonna be happy with and

175
00:09:02.620 --> 00:09:05.100
anything else looks like you're losing.

176
00:09:05.100 --> 00:09:07.945
So I think that's important.

177
00:09:07.945 --> 00:09:10.639
Cuz I think a lot of people go into those
especially with the car negotiating

178
00:09:10.639 --> 00:09:13.013
example go into that thinking,
all right, this is my opponent.

179
00:09:13.013 --> 00:09:15.039
And coming in with an open mind,

180
00:09:15.039 --> 00:09:18.880
maybe you don't tip your hand
completely at the beginning.

181
00:09:18.880 --> 00:09:22.250
But you go until they give you signs
that it's going to be a problem.

182
00:09:22.250 --> 00:09:23.860
>> And that reminds me of another idea.

183
00:09:23.860 --> 00:09:24.840
Thank you, Peter.

184
00:09:24.840 --> 00:09:26.810
Is the idea of anchoring.

185
00:09:26.810 --> 00:09:28.740
And what anchoring says is,

186
00:09:28.740 --> 00:09:32.940
you probably need to think about
the number you want and set that.

187
00:09:32.940 --> 00:09:33.660
And typically,

188
00:09:33.660 --> 00:09:38.280
whoever sets the first number sets what
the negotiations are gonna evolve around.

189
00:09:38.280 --> 00:09:43.277
If you walk in and say, I don't wanna
spend anything over $20,000 on this com,

190
00:09:43.277 --> 00:09:47.818
absolutely not, the salesperson is
gonna try to sell you something for 22.

191
00:09:47.818 --> 00:09:49.650
[LAUGH] So it's gonna be close.

192
00:09:49.650 --> 00:09:51.653
But if you say, I'm open to anything.

193
00:09:51.653 --> 00:09:55.020
I just want to get the right car,
they're gonna start you at $30,000.

194
00:09:55.020 --> 00:09:59.540
So if you can set that first number at
least you pull everything to your number.

195
00:09:59.540 --> 00:10:01.120
And you might negotiate
a little bit one way or

196
00:10:01.120 --> 00:10:04.940
the other, but you've anchored
where the negotiation will start.

197
00:10:04.940 --> 00:10:06.450
>> And I used to work with a salesperson.

198
00:10:06.450 --> 00:10:07.783
That kind of reminds me.

199
00:10:07.783 --> 00:10:11.560
They talked a lot about
whoever speaks last.

200
00:10:11.560 --> 00:10:15.520
So they would say, okay,
the price of this car is gonna be $20,000.

201
00:10:15.520 --> 00:10:17.540
And then if there's silence in the room.

202
00:10:17.540 --> 00:10:19.840
Well, that silence is awkward for
everyone and they're waiting for

203
00:10:19.840 --> 00:10:22.400
you to say, okay or how about 18?

204
00:10:22.400 --> 00:10:26.640
But if you don't say anything then
the salesperson kinda starts to feel like,

205
00:10:26.640 --> 00:10:28.500
okay, 19, how about 19?

206
00:10:28.500 --> 00:10:30.785
>> Yeah.
>> And just shut your mouth.

207
00:10:30.785 --> 00:10:33.790
[LAUGH] Put your pencil down,
just wait and listen.

208
00:10:33.790 --> 00:10:35.570
And let them come back with a number.

209
00:10:35.570 --> 00:10:38.890
>> That was a famous IBM trick.

210
00:10:38.890 --> 00:10:40.548
Whoever speaks last wins.

211
00:10:40.548 --> 00:10:44.170
Put your number on the table,
then shut up.

212
00:10:44.170 --> 00:10:48.200
There's another neat thing that
they used in IBM in sales, but

213
00:10:48.200 --> 00:10:52.420
this works with negotiations, too,
is creating what's called FUD.

214
00:10:52.420 --> 00:10:54.830
Fear, uncertainty, and doubt.

215
00:10:54.830 --> 00:11:00.220
If you can inject the element of emotion
and fear and questioning yourself, and

216
00:11:00.220 --> 00:11:06.070
doubt, you're a lot less confident in your
position, and what you're negotiating for.

217
00:11:06.070 --> 00:11:08.160
So two big ideas that came from IBM.

218
00:11:08.160 --> 00:11:10.480
>> Sounds good.
All right, so what's number four here?

219
00:11:10.480 --> 00:11:14.040
Number four is very similar to anchoring,
but

220
00:11:14.040 --> 00:11:17.300
it's making sure you don't
get off the anchoring point.

221
00:11:17.300 --> 00:11:19.070
It's called your BATNA.

222
00:11:19.070 --> 00:11:23.940
And what your BATNA is,
is your best alternative to

223
00:11:23.940 --> 00:11:27.180
a negotiated agreement, your BATNA.

224
00:11:27.180 --> 00:11:30.110
Another way to look at it,
it's your walk away point.

225
00:11:30.110 --> 00:11:33.140
What is the number or the date or the time

226
00:11:33.140 --> 00:11:37.460
that is your real line in the sand
that you absolutely can not go beyond?

227
00:11:37.460 --> 00:11:41.490
If you go beyond it you have made
a really bad deal for yourself.

228
00:11:41.490 --> 00:11:45.630
So in our car example,
I walk in with a price in my head.

229
00:11:45.630 --> 00:11:50.110
The most I can humanly pay today,
no matter what is $28000.

230
00:11:50.110 --> 00:11:51.300
That's it.

231
00:11:51.300 --> 00:11:56.273
And as soon as we get to that point, if
I'm disciplined and a good negotiator and

232
00:11:56.273 --> 00:11:59.926
they say it's $29,500,
I go, no, can't do it.

233
00:11:59.926 --> 00:12:02.640
And this can be hard sometimes.

234
00:12:02.640 --> 00:12:06.150
Selling your house,
there's tough things that if

235
00:12:06.150 --> 00:12:10.700
you don't know your BATNA before you get
there, you will almost always cross it.

236
00:12:10.700 --> 00:12:14.176
Because you're thinking in your head,
well, 28, I could probably make 29500.

237
00:12:14.176 --> 00:12:16.570
Then you get home, you realize,
I can't afford this.

238
00:12:16.570 --> 00:12:18.040
This was a bad deal.

239
00:12:18.040 --> 00:12:21.970
So you've got to clearly sit down
before you get to negotiation,

240
00:12:21.970 --> 00:12:26.412
think about what are the parameters
that make the least acceptable deal.

241
00:12:26.412 --> 00:12:29.857
What's the worst deal I can make and
still feel good about it and

242
00:12:29.857 --> 00:12:32.900
that I didn't get totally
taken advantage of?

243
00:12:32.900 --> 00:12:34.396
And that is your BATNA.

244
00:12:34.396 --> 00:12:37.140
And if it gets beyond that,
you should walk away.

245
00:12:37.140 --> 00:12:40.465
>> I feel like I do the same
thing at the black jack table.

246
00:12:40.465 --> 00:12:41.276
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'll say, all right,

247
00:12:41.276 --> 00:12:42.037
I sit down with $100.

248
00:12:42.037 --> 00:12:45.840
If I get down to zero, I'm walking away,
I'm not going to the wallet.

249
00:12:45.840 --> 00:12:48.440
But if I get up to 200,
I'm walking away then too,

250
00:12:48.440 --> 00:12:50.680
cuz I know if I keep playing
I'm gonna lose it all.

251
00:12:50.680 --> 00:12:53.290
So, going in with those expectations and
saying,

252
00:12:53.290 --> 00:12:55.730
here's what I'm gonna be happy with.

253
00:12:55.730 --> 00:12:59.170
I'd love to have this happen, but
if this happens, I need to walk away and

254
00:12:59.170 --> 00:13:00.250
step away from the table.

255
00:13:00.250 --> 00:13:02.750
>> Yeah, and that's one of the biggest
mistakes that people make.

256
00:13:02.750 --> 00:13:06.920
And it actually leads to the fifth one,
it's because they get emotional.

257
00:13:06.920 --> 00:13:11.140
They start to get angry or
upset, or excited and

258
00:13:11.140 --> 00:13:14.060
they start to make decisions
off the top of their head.

259
00:13:14.060 --> 00:13:15.390
But if you've done the other things,

260
00:13:15.390 --> 00:13:19.480
you've been well prepared, you've got lots
of ways to win, you're negotiating from

261
00:13:19.480 --> 00:13:23.862
a place that is reasonable compared to how
the other person is negotiating from you.

262
00:13:23.862 --> 00:13:28.177
You've figure out your BATNA and
you know when it's a time to walk away,

263
00:13:28.177 --> 00:13:32.580
then if you start to get emotional we
have a thing we call go to the balcony.

264
00:13:32.580 --> 00:13:36.016
And what go to the balcony means
is you try to go up above and

265
00:13:36.016 --> 00:13:41.040
look down at yourself negotiating and
saying am I following all my own rules?

266
00:13:41.040 --> 00:13:42.760
Am I keeping my data in mind?

267
00:13:42.760 --> 00:13:44.311
Am I focused on my BATNA?

268
00:13:44.311 --> 00:13:47.642
Am I getting emotional and
need to take a break?

269
00:13:47.642 --> 00:13:49.492
So-
>> That's what I thought you meant when

270
00:13:49.492 --> 00:13:53.305
you said go to the balcony of I need to
step outside for a minute and calm down.

271
00:13:53.305 --> 00:13:56.040
>> Well let's use a great
example around that.

272
00:13:56.040 --> 00:13:59.400
There's a typical negotiations gambit,
is what they call them,

273
00:13:59.400 --> 00:14:00.660
called good cop bad cop.

274
00:14:00.660 --> 00:14:04.419
This is kinda like when the car person
brings their sales manager in and

275
00:14:04.419 --> 00:14:08.943
you're negotiating and the salesperson's
like man I'd love to sell this to you for

276
00:14:08.943 --> 00:14:12.400
28,000 but my boss he's not
letting it go for under 29.

277
00:14:12.400 --> 00:14:13.640
It's not my fault.

278
00:14:13.640 --> 00:14:17.030
Then the boss comes in, the manager,
and they start to beat up on you.

279
00:14:17.030 --> 00:14:20.822
This is oftentimes just a tactic,
a trick, to put pressure on you.

280
00:14:20.822 --> 00:14:25.698
And what you do then is you say I had
a big Diet Coke before I came in,

281
00:14:25.698 --> 00:14:28.020
and I just need a minute or two.

282
00:14:28.020 --> 00:14:32.250
Why don't you guys talk amongst yourselves
and I'll be back in four or five minutes.

283
00:14:32.250 --> 00:14:34.420
And you go off and go to the balcony.

284
00:14:34.420 --> 00:14:37.120
Rest, relax, regain, come back.

285
00:14:37.120 --> 00:14:40.530
If they're still angry,
one's still angry, you say,

286
00:14:40.530 --> 00:14:44.460
you seem a little frustrated and
possibly need to take a breather.

287
00:14:44.460 --> 00:14:46.865
And actually I'm a little thirsty, you
have any water, could I have some water?

288
00:14:46.865 --> 00:14:49.140
[LAUGH] And you go take another break.

289
00:14:49.140 --> 00:14:54.620
Here's what happens, after two or three
times they either, you figured out that

290
00:14:54.620 --> 00:14:58.760
one is actually against you or
it's a trick and they'll quit it.

291
00:14:58.760 --> 00:15:00.940
Or you can use one other thing which
is fine, I'll just put this out.

292
00:15:00.940 --> 00:15:02.240
If one plays good cop and

293
00:15:02.240 --> 00:15:05.670
the other one plays bad cop, what you
do is you ask the bad cop to leave and

294
00:15:05.670 --> 00:15:08.510
you tell the good cop, hey listen,
we're on the same team here man.

295
00:15:08.510 --> 00:15:09.510
We both want the same thing.

296
00:15:09.510 --> 00:15:10.740
We've been working on this.

297
00:15:10.740 --> 00:15:11.900
You're really on my team, right?

298
00:15:11.900 --> 00:15:13.680
And they say yeah,
I'm trying to help you John.

299
00:15:13.680 --> 00:15:15.860
I can't understand why he's
not negotiating with us.

300
00:15:15.860 --> 00:15:16.860
It's driving me crazy.

301
00:15:16.860 --> 00:15:21.190
And you say great, then I want you
to go negotiate with him for me, and

302
00:15:21.190 --> 00:15:22.750
come back with my answer.

303
00:15:22.750 --> 00:15:26.980
And tell him or her that, if they continue
to be aggressive, rude, angry, or mean,

304
00:15:26.980 --> 00:15:28.640
I'm just gonna get up and leave.

305
00:15:28.640 --> 00:15:30.460
And you pit them against themselves.

306
00:15:30.460 --> 00:15:33.500
So if you go out enough times and
calm down, or

307
00:15:33.500 --> 00:15:37.130
you pit them against themselves,
typically they'll end the tactic.

308
00:15:37.130 --> 00:15:38.550
They'll realize it isn't gonna work.

309
00:15:38.550 --> 00:15:42.709
However, if they continue to do that, what
they've told you is one of them really is

310
00:15:42.709 --> 00:15:44.716
angry, mad, or upset, or maybe both.

311
00:15:44.716 --> 00:15:47.380
And here's a big,
big key point I can end on.

312
00:15:47.380 --> 00:15:51.290
Never, ever negotiate with someone
that's angry or aggressive or

313
00:15:51.290 --> 00:15:54.830
highly emotional, cuz it is impossible

314
00:15:54.830 --> 00:15:59.760
to get to a win-win agreement negotiating
with someone that doesn't want you to win.

315
00:15:59.760 --> 00:16:02.940
>> Well, John, I was about to tell you,
we're kind of ramped up on time here,

316
00:16:02.940 --> 00:16:04.490
and was gonna look for a key takeaway.

317
00:16:04.490 --> 00:16:05.570
That sounds like a great one.

318
00:16:05.570 --> 00:16:08.255
And also, what did you say earlier,
the most prepared-

319
00:16:08.255 --> 00:16:10.312
>> Who's ever the best prepared to win,

320
00:16:10.312 --> 00:16:13.170
and has the most ways to win,
typically wins.

321
00:16:13.170 --> 00:16:16.940
>> Fantastic I think thats a great place
for us to stop for negotiating, but

322
00:16:16.940 --> 00:16:20.990
we got a lot of great episodes coming up
in this professional development series.

323
00:16:20.990 --> 00:16:25.430
So, be sure to stay tuned for those, but
for now were gonna go ahead and sign off.

324
00:16:25.430 --> 00:16:28.080
For Biz pro TV,
Ive been your host Peter Vanrysban.

325
00:16:28.080 --> 00:16:28.960
>> And Im John Spence.

326
00:16:28.960 --> 00:16:29.800
>> And well see you next time.

327
00:16:29.800 --> 00:16:38.699

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.115
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.115 --> 00:00:07.808
[SOUND] Hello, and welcome to BizProTV.

3
00:00:07.808 --> 00:00:09.829
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam, and today,

4
00:00:09.829 --> 00:00:13.190
we're continuing in our series
about professional development.

5
00:00:13.190 --> 00:00:16.290
And specifically today, we're talking
about something I could've used in a lot

6
00:00:16.290 --> 00:00:19.570
of my relationships at
home conflict resolution.

7
00:00:19.570 --> 00:00:23.230
And here to help us is someone who,
we haven't had any conflicts yet,

8
00:00:23.230 --> 00:00:24.750
but we'll see.

9
00:00:24.750 --> 00:00:25.870
So John Spence, how you doing?

10
00:00:25.870 --> 00:00:27.460
>> I'm doing great.
I'm looking forward to this too.

11
00:00:27.460 --> 00:00:30.280
I think it's one of those things you
should have been taught at an early age,

12
00:00:30.280 --> 00:00:31.920
and most of it learn it by chance.

13
00:00:31.920 --> 00:00:34.009
>> Yeah, definitely.
I think within business,

14
00:00:34.009 --> 00:00:39.189
there's oftentimes a lot of conflict,
personalities clash, things like that,

15
00:00:39.189 --> 00:00:43.270
or even in negotiations in meetings
if you have different ideas.

16
00:00:43.270 --> 00:00:46.260
So where do we start
with conflict resolution?

17
00:00:46.260 --> 00:00:48.678
>> Well we start with first the idea,
that conflict can be healthy.

18
00:00:48.678 --> 00:00:53.310
There is some good interactions,

19
00:00:53.310 --> 00:00:58.210
maybe some strong interactions,
really getting excited, or motivated,

20
00:00:58.210 --> 00:01:03.200
or passionate about something,
is not necessarily a negative conflict.

21
00:01:03.200 --> 00:01:04.680
One of my clients, Microsoft,

22
00:01:04.680 --> 00:01:08.910
has a great saying,
that people are safe, ideas are not.

23
00:01:08.910 --> 00:01:12.360
And the idea when they get in a meeting
is, I'm not going to attack anyone at

24
00:01:12.360 --> 00:01:15.310
the table, but I'm gonna rip every
idea apart, make it the best I can.

25
00:01:15.310 --> 00:01:18.810
And I think that's a great
example of very healthy conflict.

26
00:01:18.810 --> 00:01:23.210
>> And it sounds like, maybe don't take
an idea that you had too personally then.

27
00:01:23.210 --> 00:01:25.700
This is just your idea that
you're throwing out and

28
00:01:25.700 --> 00:01:29.770
if the idea gets ripped apart,
that's the idea, and not you as a person.

29
00:01:29.770 --> 00:01:32.480
>> Yeah, and
because it's everyone's job there.

30
00:01:32.480 --> 00:01:35.580
They tell everybody when we go
into one of these sessions,

31
00:01:35.580 --> 00:01:38.050
the goal is to get the best idea.

32
00:01:38.050 --> 00:01:41.730
So all of you should throw in other ideas,
other suggestions, and

33
00:01:41.730 --> 00:01:45.540
do your best to make whatever great
idea somebody put out even better.

34
00:01:45.540 --> 00:01:47.180
So nobody takes it personally.

35
00:01:47.180 --> 00:01:50.970
It's the way that they do the same thing
when someone else throws out an idea.

36
00:01:50.970 --> 00:01:55.240
Another big thing around conflict
is mostly it isn't me versus you.

37
00:01:55.240 --> 00:01:56.280
It's a miscommunication.

38
00:01:57.280 --> 00:02:00.780
Someone didn't fully understand
what the other person was saying.

39
00:02:00.780 --> 00:02:02.360
They made an assumption.

40
00:02:02.360 --> 00:02:06.690
They inferred things, or they simply

But that is kind of a great point for

00:13:48.490 --> 00:13:52.000
us to leave off on this episode

00:13:52.000 --> 00:13:54.540
But we've got a lot more great

00:13:54.540 --> 00:13:57.480
professional development skills, so

00:13:57.480 --> 00:13:59.770

4

00:00:12.770 --> 00:00:16.840
And specifically, in this episode,

6
00:00:16.840 --> 00:00:19.670
career development, and here to help

7
00:00:19.670 --> 00:00:23.810
The entrepreneur, the speaker,
the business coach, the everything,

00:00:23.810 --> 00:00:24.430
John Spence.

00:00:24.430 --> 00:00:25.065

00:00:25.065 --> 00:00:25.800

00:00:25.800 --> 00:00:26.358
Thanks Peter.

12
00:00:26.358 --> 00:00:29.145
>> All right, so what are we talking
