13
00:00:29.145 --> 00:00:33.241
>> Oftentimes I'm asked to give talks
at universities, or things like that,

14
00:00:33.241 --> 00:00:36.899
about what are the most important
elements to build a great career.

15
00:00:36.899 --> 00:00:40.638
And this works anywhere in your career,
but they're things that I see as

16
00:00:40.638 --> 00:00:44.502
fundamental to truly building a highly
successful career that you enjoy,

17
00:00:44.502 --> 00:00:48.500
that you're passionate about,
and that you're very good at.

18
00:00:48.500 --> 00:00:51.840
And I'm gonna be borrowing from
a couple of my friends that are authors

19
00:00:51.840 --> 00:00:57.070
that have really put forward some great
ideas that are succinct and spot on.

20
00:00:57.070 --> 00:01:00.200
And the first one is from a friend
of mine named Tim Sanders.

21
00:01:00.200 --> 00:01:03.110
And Tim wrote a great book
called Love is the Killer App,

22
00:01:03.110 --> 00:01:05.460
as in application as IT thing there.

23
00:01:05.460 --> 00:01:09.020
And what he talked about is
the three key things it takes

24
00:01:09.020 --> 00:01:10.310
to build a world class career.

25
00:01:10.310 --> 00:01:12.080
And I think he just nailed it here.

26
00:01:12.080 --> 00:01:17.240
And the three things are K-N-L, K-N-L.

27
00:01:17.240 --> 00:01:19.080
The K stands for knowledge.

28
00:01:19.080 --> 00:01:21.010
You've got to be bright, sharp, smart,

29
00:01:21.010 --> 00:01:24.880
and talented at something that's
highly valuable in the marketplace.

30
00:01:24.880 --> 00:01:27.050
You've got to have skills, ideas,

31
00:01:27.050 --> 00:01:32.340
expertise, information that people
are more than willing to pay for.

32
00:01:32.340 --> 00:01:35.970
So you've got to be highly
knowledgeable at something that's very,

33
00:01:35.970 --> 00:01:37.550
very valuable in the marketplace.

34
00:01:37.550 --> 00:01:38.950
That's the K.

35
00:01:38.950 --> 00:01:41.040
The N stands for network.

36
00:01:41.040 --> 00:01:44.340
A lot of the right people need to know
that about you, and by right people,

37
00:01:44.340 --> 00:01:46.350
it's what I call hubs.

38
00:01:46.350 --> 00:01:49.460
And a hub is somebody that,
by the nature of who they are,

39
00:01:49.460 --> 00:01:54.510
if they're really impressed with what
you know, they don't tell a few people.

40
00:01:54.510 --> 00:01:58.270
They tell a few hundred, a few thousand,
or a few hundred thousand, or more.

41
00:01:58.270 --> 00:02:00.170
I'll give you a great example.

42
00:02:00.170 --> 00:02:04.670
When I wrote my book Awesomely Simple
several years ago it was doing okay.

43
00:02:04.670 --> 00:02:07.120
It won a few awards, not that great.

44
00:02:07.120 --> 00:02:12.150
And it was number 1131 on the bestseller's
list on Amazon, not so much.

45
00:02:13.220 --> 00:02:16.530
But then Guy Kawasaki, a colleague,

46
00:02:16.530 --> 00:02:20.850
the former marketing director at Apple was
kind enough to put out a tweet about it.

47
00:02:20.850 --> 00:02:23.890
And he suggested, read John Spence's book,
Awesomely Simple,

48
00:02:23.890 --> 00:02:25.710
really good, I highly recommend it.

49
00:02:25.710 --> 00:02:31.120
Sent it out, and I went from number
1131 to number 11 in one day and

50
00:02:31.120 --> 00:02:33.985
got back ordered at Amazon for
a full month and a half.

51
00:02:33.985 --> 00:02:35.472
The reason?

52
00:02:35.472 --> 00:02:38.300
He has 1.8 million Twitter followers.

53
00:02:38.300 --> 00:02:40.060
So the idea here is yes,

54
00:02:40.060 --> 00:02:44.690
I want to meet anyone I can, anyone of
quality, integrity, that has great ideas.

55
00:02:44.690 --> 00:02:47.080
I want a great network around me.

56
00:02:47.080 --> 00:02:52.430
But I also especially want to focus on the
hubs, the people that know if I'm really,

57
00:02:52.430 --> 00:02:56.170
really good at what I do,
then they can tell a lot of people.

58
00:02:56.170 --> 00:02:58.975
As long as you have the third element,
which is love,

59
00:02:58.975 --> 00:03:01.980
it's knowledge, network, love.

60
00:03:01.980 --> 00:03:04.370
And love says, if you're an honest, kind,

61
00:03:04.370 --> 00:03:07.750
loving person of integrity,
you've got an amazing reputation for

62
00:03:07.750 --> 00:03:11.950
telling the truth, a lot of the right
people know that about you, hubs.

63
00:03:11.950 --> 00:03:13.420
And they also know that you're really,

64
00:03:13.420 --> 00:03:17.530
really good at something that's highly
valuable in the marketplace, you have any

65
00:03:17.530 --> 00:03:22.290
job, in any company, anywhere in the world
at about any reasonable price you want.

66
00:03:22.290 --> 00:03:25.540
So the three questions you have
to ask yourself everyday are,

67
00:03:25.540 --> 00:03:30.560
what did I learn today, who did I meet
today, and did I live my values today?

68
00:03:30.560 --> 00:03:33.478
And I think if you focus on those
three things that builds a really good

69
00:03:33.478 --> 00:03:34.570
foundation.

70
00:03:34.570 --> 00:03:38.290
>> Well, it's kind of easy to understand
the knowledge and the process for

71
00:03:38.290 --> 00:03:42.860
that, and the networking as well,
and planning to do that, and

72
00:03:42.860 --> 00:03:43.920
figuring out the skills for that.

73
00:03:43.920 --> 00:03:45.820
But the love kind of seems
like the tricky one.

74
00:03:45.820 --> 00:03:50.490
So what are some things that I can do to
make sure that people that I meet and

75
00:03:50.490 --> 00:03:53.820
know that I am knowledgeable will
take tha extra step and refer me?

76
00:03:55.100 --> 00:03:57.960
>> Well it's interesting
you used the word refer.

77
00:03:57.960 --> 00:04:02.590
Because, people think referrals are for
your business, bringing in more customers,

78
00:04:02.590 --> 00:04:06.140
and they are, but you also want
referrals for you as a professional and

79
00:04:06.140 --> 00:04:08.550
that's not just externally,
it's internally as well.

80
00:04:08.550 --> 00:04:12.530
You want people inside of your company, if
you work in large corporation, to refer to

81
00:04:12.530 --> 00:04:16.840
you as someone who's excellent to other
departments, their boss, up the chain.

82
00:04:16.840 --> 00:04:19.720
If you're working with different
companies you want referrals.

83
00:04:19.720 --> 00:04:23.260
So, referrals are actually for
everybody, and a couple of years ago,

84
00:04:23.260 --> 00:04:27.870
a friend of mine recommended I get
a book specifically on referrals.

85
00:04:27.870 --> 00:04:32.350
Now I won't give you the title of it, but
I went to order it at Amazon.com, and

86
00:04:32.350 --> 00:04:33.240
I buy a lot of books.

87
00:04:33.240 --> 00:04:38.850
I read over 100 business books a year,
and I go there, and the book is $68.

88
00:04:38.850 --> 00:04:43.747
And I'm used to paying $10, $12 for
an e-book or maybe 25 for a normal book,

89
00:04:43.747 --> 00:04:46.990
$70 for book, but
my friend said it was great.

90
00:04:46.990 --> 00:04:51.637
So, I hit the one click and ordered and
it showed up at my house, gets there,

91
00:04:51.637 --> 00:04:55.138
it's 26 pages long with big pictures and
blank pages.

92
00:04:55.138 --> 00:04:58.530
I mean the worst thing it have been it
would only bad if it been a pop-up book,

93
00:04:58.530 --> 00:05:00.450
woulda been the only thing that was worse.

94
00:05:00.450 --> 00:05:04.038
So I'm reading through it and
I see one of the chapter titles says,

95
00:05:04.038 --> 00:05:06.350
the four keys to referability.

96
00:05:06.350 --> 00:05:10.810
And my entire business
generates around referability,

97
00:05:10.810 --> 00:05:13.210
inside of companies and
outside of companies.

98
00:05:13.210 --> 00:05:15.190
So I flipped there real quick, and

99
00:05:15.190 --> 00:05:18.760
there were four ideas there that I looked
at them when I first heard them and

100
00:05:18.760 --> 00:05:21.620
said, this is the stupidest
stuff I've ever seen.

101
00:05:21.620 --> 00:05:23.000
This is just so mundane.

102
00:05:23.000 --> 00:05:24.940
It doesn't, it's crazy.

103
00:05:24.940 --> 00:05:28.160
And at the time my wife and
I owned two companies together and

104
00:05:28.160 --> 00:05:30.150
we were building a custom home.

105
00:05:30.150 --> 00:05:34.200
And I went and read them to her and
I said, sweetheart, and here they are,

106
00:05:34.200 --> 00:05:39.260
show up on time, do what you say
you will do, finish what you start,

107
00:05:39.260 --> 00:05:40.490
say please and thank you.

108
00:05:40.490 --> 00:05:44.000
I added a fifth, which is always give
just a little bit more than they expect.

109
00:05:44.000 --> 00:05:46.000
But he had four in the book and
I added the fifth.

110
00:05:46.000 --> 00:05:47.886
So I went to my wife, and I went, honey,

111
00:05:47.886 --> 00:05:51.269
out of all the people we work with in
our two companies, all our vendors,

112
00:05:51.269 --> 00:05:54.399
everything, and all of the people
working on our house right now.

113
00:05:54.399 --> 00:05:59.377
Can you name one that consistently
shows up on time, does everything they

114
00:05:59.377 --> 00:06:04.436
say they will do, finishes everything
they start, always says please and

115
00:06:04.436 --> 00:06:09.033
thank you, and always give us just
a little bit more than we expect?

116
00:06:09.033 --> 00:06:11.350
And the answer was no.

117
00:06:11.350 --> 00:06:13.320
I bet you would have
a hard time doing that.

118
00:06:13.320 --> 00:06:17.010
I mean, if I know someone that
meets those criteria consistently

119
00:06:17.010 --> 00:06:19.600
I become a raving fan for that company.

120
00:06:19.600 --> 00:06:21.050
I tell everybody.

121
00:06:21.050 --> 00:06:23.360
I want everybody to know I've
got a place I eat breakfast.

122
00:06:23.360 --> 00:06:27.190
When I'm not traveling I eat breakfast at
the same place for the last 15 years, and

123
00:06:27.190 --> 00:06:29.680
I love it and I tell everybody about it.

124
00:06:29.680 --> 00:06:35.800
So the idea here is in your career, if you
can consistently do those five things.

125
00:06:35.800 --> 00:06:38.810
Show up on time, do what you say you'll
do, finish what you start, say please and

126
00:06:38.810 --> 00:06:41.610
thank you, and
always keep a little bit more than expect,

127
00:06:41.610 --> 00:06:45.860
you will be building an incredibly strong
foundation for taking your career forward.

128
00:06:45.860 --> 00:06:49.799
>> I'm sorry, I haven't been paying
the most attention cuz I've been trying to

129
00:06:49.799 --> 00:06:53.857
go back while you've been talking and
figure out so that's $68 for the book,

130
00:06:53.857 --> 00:06:56.645
four ideas, what is that,
$17 an idea basically?

131
00:06:56.645 --> 00:06:58.972
>> [LAUGH]
>> If my math is right, but.

132
00:06:58.972 --> 00:07:02.360
[LAUGH]
>> Well the gentleman that I got this from

133
00:07:03.440 --> 00:07:06.090
charges $50,000 a day for
personal coaching.

134
00:07:07.170 --> 00:07:12.480
Because ideas like that, although they
look simple can be life changing.

135
00:07:12.480 --> 00:07:15.670
I've taught that idea all over the world,
and all over the world,

136
00:07:15.670 --> 00:07:16.720
people say the same thing.

137
00:07:16.720 --> 00:07:21.340
I don't know anyone, or very few people
know anyone that meets those criteria.

138
00:07:21.340 --> 00:07:25.260
Which means if you went back and said, I'm
gonna be one of the people that meets all

139
00:07:25.260 --> 00:07:28.430
five of those criteria, you would
absolutely crush the competition.

140
00:07:28.430 --> 00:07:29.110
>> That's fantastic.

141
00:07:29.110 --> 00:07:32.419
Well what other points do we have
here about career development?

142
00:07:33.740 --> 00:07:36.470
>> One of the other things, and
you were starting to ask about the love,

143
00:07:36.470 --> 00:07:38.630
that sounded a little bit
ambiguous to you a little.

144
00:07:38.630 --> 00:07:39.830
How do you do that?

145
00:07:39.830 --> 00:07:40.780
It's very simple.

146
00:07:40.780 --> 00:07:47.140
I've got a Walt Disney quote I love,
when values are clear, decisions are easy.

147
00:07:47.140 --> 00:07:48.990
So the next step is,

148
00:07:48.990 --> 00:07:54.150
to matching that knowledge network love
part, is what are your core values?

149
00:07:54.150 --> 00:07:59.000
What are the three, four, five, six things
you hold very dearly as the way you

150
00:07:59.000 --> 00:08:03.300
wanna live your life, the person you wanna
be, the reputation you wanna create,

151
00:08:03.300 --> 00:08:05.130
the image you wanna portray?

152
00:08:05.130 --> 00:08:06.781
And write those down and

153
00:08:06.781 --> 00:08:10.130
then measure everything you do in
your life against those values.

154
00:08:10.130 --> 00:08:14.120
Again, teaching this for more than 20
years, I will challenge people in my

155
00:08:14.120 --> 00:08:18.380
classes, how many of you now have
a written list of your core values?

156
00:08:18.380 --> 00:08:22.770
And maybe only 5 to 8% of
the people will raise their hand.

157
00:08:22.770 --> 00:08:26.140
So it's very hard to make good decisions

158
00:08:26.140 --> 00:08:27.930
when you don't know what
you're basing them on.

159
00:08:27.930 --> 00:08:30.230
Let me reverse that to make
it even more powerful.

160
00:08:30.230 --> 00:08:34.350
You can make even the most difficult and
challenging decisions in your life about

161
00:08:34.350 --> 00:08:38.970
your family, your career, whatever it
might be, if you have really clear values.

162
00:08:38.970 --> 00:08:40.290
Because you just look at the value and

163
00:08:40.290 --> 00:08:43.560
say, is what I'm about to do
right now gonna match that value?

164
00:08:43.560 --> 00:08:48.390
And that's big about the love part with
integrity, honesty, and reputation.

165
00:08:48.390 --> 00:08:51.620
>> And that's something that we take
seriously here at BizProTV, and

166
00:08:51.620 --> 00:08:54.630
that's why I love working here and
the parent company Edutainment Live.

167
00:08:54.630 --> 00:08:56.450
We have our five main values.

168
00:08:56.450 --> 00:09:00.260
And whenever we have a tough decision and
we're debating back and forth,

169
00:09:00.260 --> 00:09:03.870
we'll always kind of step back and say,
well, how does this relate to our values?

170
00:09:03.870 --> 00:09:07.690
And, for example, the biggest one
is we exist for our members, for

171
00:09:07.690 --> 00:09:08.740
the people out there watching.

172
00:09:08.740 --> 00:09:12.430
And so, oftentimes it'll make
those five choices you had, well,

173
00:09:12.430 --> 00:09:14.450
it becomes clear that we
wanna go with this one.

174
00:09:14.450 --> 00:09:18.880
Because that is what helps us offer
the best product to our members,

175
00:09:18.880 --> 00:09:23.320
so having those values identified before
we go into these kind of decision making

176
00:09:23.320 --> 00:09:25.810
things helps us come up
with the best answer.

177
00:09:25.810 --> 00:09:28.030
>> And in business that makes total sense.

178
00:09:28.030 --> 00:09:32.650
We've got our mission, our vision,
our values, our core purpose.

179
00:09:32.650 --> 00:09:35.850
Most companies would never think of trying
to go forward in being a successful

180
00:09:35.850 --> 00:09:37.930
company without having
those things in place.

181
00:09:37.930 --> 00:09:39.986
It's exact same for your life.

182
00:09:39.986 --> 00:09:43.176
What are your core value,
what's your mission, what's your purpose,

183
00:09:43.176 --> 00:09:46.624
another thing that I think fits in this
well is what's your personal definition

184
00:09:46.624 --> 00:09:47.712
of success?

185
00:09:47.712 --> 00:09:50.320
In a business we measure this pretty
easily, it's the bottom line,

186
00:09:50.320 --> 00:09:52.010
it's how big our market share is,

187
00:09:52.010 --> 00:09:55.840
it's how much we give back to
the community, we can put a number on it.

188
00:09:55.840 --> 00:10:00.660
But sort of like, it's tough to make great
decisions if you don't have clear values.

189
00:10:00.660 --> 00:10:03.470
It's very hard to feel successful

190
00:10:03.470 --> 00:10:06.170
if you've never defined
what success is for you.

191
00:10:06.170 --> 00:10:09.980
And the big idea around this is
everybody's definition is different.

192
00:10:09.980 --> 00:10:14.650
In America, we typically, and
even if you look up the definition,

193
00:10:14.650 --> 00:10:17.850
believe that success is money,
fame and power.

194
00:10:17.850 --> 00:10:20.620
You've got to be really rich,
extremely famous and

195
00:10:20.620 --> 00:10:23.980
very powerful to be
considered highly successful.

196
00:10:23.980 --> 00:10:27.080
I'm fine with all those things,
if that's really what you value.

197
00:10:27.080 --> 00:10:32.340
But my definition of personal success
is when your self-concept and

198
00:10:32.340 --> 00:10:35.820
core values are in harmony
with your daily behaviors.

199
00:10:35.820 --> 00:10:39.040
In other words,
you thought deeply about who you wanna be,

200
00:10:39.040 --> 00:10:43.050
what your core values are, what you really
stand for, any thought about, I got

201
00:10:43.050 --> 00:10:46.150
up every day of my life with just awesome,
I was having fun and I enjoyed it.

202
00:10:46.150 --> 00:10:49.420
And then you get up everyday and
you actually lived that.

203
00:10:49.420 --> 00:10:51.280
You might become rich,
famous, and powerful.

204
00:10:51.280 --> 00:10:52.860
No one in the world might know you.

205
00:10:52.860 --> 00:10:55.390
It doesn't matter as long as you can put
your head on your pillow at night and

206
00:10:55.390 --> 00:11:00.140
go, another fantastic day, lived my
values, life is the way I want it to be,

207
00:11:00.140 --> 00:11:01.600
this is fantastic.

208
00:11:01.600 --> 00:11:06.830
So another challenge in this is write down
your own personal definition of success.

209

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:07.628
[SOUND] Hello, and welcome to BizProTV.

00:00:07.628 --> 00:00:11.189
I'm your host, Peter VanRysdam, and

00:00:11.189 --> 00:00:14.205

5
00:00:16.800 --> 00:00:19.470
And here to help us,

6
00:00:19.470 --> 00:00:20.210
John, how you doing?

7
00:00:20.210 --> 00:00:21.550
>> I'm doing great today, Peter, you?

8
00:00:21.550 --> 00:00:23.490
>> I am fantastic, thank you.

9
00:00:23.490 --> 00:00:27.917
I'm a big believer in delegation and
making sure that you have a team that for

10
00:00:27.917 --> 00:00:31.664
a lot of people, it's threatening
to have a really great team.

11
00:00:31.664 --> 00:00:34.854

than me and really rely on them for

00:00:34.854 --> 00:00:37.590

that's what I've done with my team here.

13
00:00:37.590 --> 00:00:41.140
But what are you talking about
when we say, delegating down?

14
00:00:41.140 --> 00:00:43.200
>> Well, and
it's delegating down or across.

15
00:00:43.200 --> 00:00:47.512
It's hard to delegate to your peers a lot,
that's more of a negotiation,

16
00:00:47.512 --> 00:00:49.160
as we talked about earlier.

17
00:00:49.160 --> 00:00:53.920
But what I'm looking at here is, and it's
a very simple idea, with the speed and

18
00:00:53.920 --> 00:00:57.330
pace of business today,
you can't do it alone.

19
00:00:57.330 --> 00:00:59.330
Nobody can, things move too fast.

20
00:00:59.330 --> 00:01:03.410
There's too many moving parts, too much
stuff happening in the marketplace, and

00:01:03.410 --> 00:01:05.550
you've got to have people
on your team to help you.

22
00:01:05.550 --> 00:01:06.920
And of course, and

23
00:01:06.920 --> 00:01:10.110
you said something interesting that
I'll bring up a little research on it.

24
00:01:10.110 --> 00:01:13.900
There was a large research
project a couple years ago.

25
00:01:13.900 --> 00:01:18.100
They looked at about 8,000,
quote unquote, leaders, senior managers.

26
00:01:18.100 --> 00:01:20.850
And they said,
what kind of a follower do you wanna have?

27
00:01:20.850 --> 00:01:23.830
Do you wanna have someone
that's a yes man or woman?

28
00:01:23.830 --> 00:01:26.630
Who, whatever you say, sure,
I gotta handle whatever you say.

29
00:01:26.630 --> 00:01:31.177
Or the fence sitter, who sort of waits and
sees and makes sure it's a good idea.

30
00:01:31.177 --> 00:01:34.570
And as soon as everybody else is on board,
it's going good, they jump on board.

31
00:01:34.570 --> 00:01:35.825
>> See which way the wind's blowing.

32
00:01:35.825 --> 00:01:38.100
>> [LAUGH] Exactly,
see which way the wind's blowing.

33
00:01:38.100 --> 00:01:40.940
And then you've got the people
who are the challengers.

34
00:01:40.940 --> 00:01:42.990
Who are constantly challenging your ideas,

35
00:01:42.990 --> 00:01:47.730
trying to make them better, asking why,
bringing up other data, other information.

36
00:01:47.730 --> 00:01:51.610
And they ask these folks, who would
you like to have as your followers?

37
00:01:51.610 --> 00:01:54.650
And what do you think
the number one answer was?

38
00:01:54.650 --> 00:01:56.190
>> Well, I know what I think it should be,

39
00:01:56.190 --> 00:01:58.076
but I'm guessing most
people said the yes men.

40
00:01:58.076 --> 00:01:59.181
[LAUGH]
>> Yes,

41
00:01:59.181 --> 00:02:04.930
82% of the people said I'd prefer to
have yes men or women on my team.

42
00:02:04.930 --> 00:02:06.946
Only about 5% wanted the challengers,

43
00:02:06.946 --> 00:02:10.880
which is the exact opposite of the way
it should be, as you pointed out.

44
00:02:10.880 --> 00:02:14.742
I want people on my team that are smart,
fast, bright, and smarter than me, which,

45
00:02:14.742 --> 00:02:16.796
for you and I,
is not too high of a challenge.

46
00:02:16.796 --> 00:02:17.787
>> No.
>> [LAUGH] But

47
00:02:17.787 --> 00:02:22.960
when you do have to delegate to those
folks, you've gotta look at it this way.

48
00:02:22.960 --> 00:02:24.422
You're juggling a lot
of balls as a manager.

49
00:02:24.422 --> 00:02:28.320
You gotta figure out which ones
are rubber and which ones are crystal.

50
00:02:28.320 --> 00:02:31.280
The rubber balls, you can drop and
let other people pick up.

51
00:02:31.280 --> 00:02:35.330
If you drop one of the glass or
crystal balls, it's in serious trouble.

52
00:02:35.330 --> 00:02:38.840
So part of it is backing up and
saying, what can I say no to?

53
00:02:38.840 --> 00:02:42.220
What can I trust other people
to do as well or better than me?

54
00:02:42.220 --> 00:02:46.240
Not just exactly the way I would do it,
but that the outcome would be there, and

55
00:02:46.240 --> 00:02:48.210
then learn to delegate to them.

56
00:02:48.210 --> 00:02:50.740
I learned this when I
was a very young CEO.

57
00:02:50.740 --> 00:02:52.660
When I first got in,
I thought this is great,

58
00:02:52.660 --> 00:02:57.610
I have the corner office, got glass walls,
and I get to make all the decisions.

59
00:02:57.610 --> 00:03:00.010
Everything had to come across my table.

60
00:03:00.010 --> 00:03:02.870
Until I looked up one day and
realized my entire staff was standing

61
00:03:02.870 --> 00:03:05.250
down the hallway waiting for
me to make decisions.

62
00:03:05.250 --> 00:03:07.070
I was the bottleneck in the company.

63
00:03:07.070 --> 00:03:10.530
All of the work was being held up because
I was trying to oversee all of it.

64
00:03:10.530 --> 00:03:12.980
And I was afraid,
as you mentioned, to delegate.

65
00:03:12.980 --> 00:03:14.600
So I brought my whole staff together,
and I said,

66
00:03:14.600 --> 00:03:17.840
from now on,
there's four levels of delegation.

67
00:03:17.840 --> 00:03:22.690
Level one, it's your decision to the staff
person, this is what I hired you for.

68
00:03:22.690 --> 00:03:25.960
You're better at it then me, you've
got more experience, more knowledge.

69
00:03:25.960 --> 00:03:29.933
You just make this decision totally on
your own, and then you own the outcome.

70
00:03:29.933 --> 00:03:32.358
Level one, your decision,
you own the outcome.

71
00:03:32.358 --> 00:03:36.000
Level two, you probably need to
get some feedback on this, but

72
00:03:36.000 --> 00:03:37.640
it doesn't have to be from me.

73
00:03:37.640 --> 00:03:41.900
It might be from the CFO, or the head of
marketing, or our membership director,

74
00:03:41.900 --> 00:03:44.760
whatever it might be,
or the IT department.

75
00:03:44.760 --> 00:03:46.650
Go get some feedback, some advice.

76
00:03:46.650 --> 00:03:49.080
Then you make the decision and you own it.

77
00:03:49.080 --> 00:03:50.960
And after you've asked for
advice a couple of times,

78
00:03:50.960 --> 00:03:53.160
it should switch to a level one decision.

79
00:03:53.160 --> 00:03:54.730
Level one, you make it, you own it.

80
00:03:54.730 --> 00:03:58.860
Level two, get some advice, input,
you make the decision, you own it.

81
00:03:58.860 --> 00:04:01.140
Level three, it's a team decision.

82
00:04:01.140 --> 00:04:03.433
We're gonna pull everybody together and,
or

83
00:04:03.433 --> 00:04:05.736
the appropriate people
together on the team.

84
00:04:05.736 --> 00:04:09.341
And we're gonna talk about this,
discuss it, and as a team, together,

85
00:04:09.341 --> 00:04:11.270
we're gonna decide on the direction.

86
00:04:12.510 --> 00:04:16.457
And even if I, as the manager or
leader, do not agree with you,

87
00:04:16.457 --> 00:04:21.073
if the entire team says go this way, and
I say I think we should go that way,

88
00:04:21.073 --> 00:04:24.975
I'm going to make the decision
the way the team wants to do it.

89
00:04:24.975 --> 00:04:28.470
And the team will not own it,
I will own it.

90
00:04:28.470 --> 00:04:32.230
So level three says team decision and
then whatever the team decides,

91
00:04:32.230 --> 00:04:35.480
I as the leader make the decision
that way, go along with it.

92
00:04:35.480 --> 00:04:38.150
And I represent that decision
as if it were my own.

93
00:04:38.150 --> 00:04:42.360
That's level three, level four is
it's my decision as the leader.

94
00:04:42.360 --> 00:04:46.630
I'm gonna do what I think I need to do, I
might ask for your feedback, I might not.

95
00:04:46.630 --> 00:04:49.170
I might have more information,
a higher view.

96
00:04:49.170 --> 00:04:51.020
I might know something you don't know.

97
00:04:51.020 --> 00:04:53.180
But I'm gonna make this decision,
I own it.

98
00:04:53.180 --> 00:04:54.740
But I need you to follow it.

99
00:04:54.740 --> 00:04:57.880
Which is why the level three of
I'm gonna follow your decision,

100
00:04:57.880 --> 00:05:00.780
I'll take responsibility for
it, allows you to

101
00:05:00.780 --> 00:05:03.620
have this level four decision where
you're saying, I make the decision.

102
00:05:03.620 --> 00:05:05.930
I need you to trust me and follow me.

103
00:05:05.930 --> 00:05:07.340
Here's what I found out.

104
00:05:07.340 --> 00:05:11.810
About 70%, 80% of the decisions I
was making were one, two, or three.

105
00:05:11.810 --> 00:05:14.490
Probably 60% of them were level one.

106
00:05:14.490 --> 00:05:17.680
So, after that then, when someone
would come to my office and say, John,

107
00:05:17.680 --> 00:05:20.170
I really need help, I'd go mm-mm,
level one, level one.

108
00:05:20.170 --> 00:05:21.750
Go back, make the decision.

109
00:05:21.750 --> 00:05:24.320
Or they come in, John, I really,
I go, no, no, level two.

110
00:05:24.320 --> 00:05:27.940
Go talk to Peter, or go talk to Tim,
or go talk to Robin.

111
00:05:27.940 --> 00:05:29.340
I don't have the information on that.

112
00:05:29.340 --> 00:05:33.510
Go talk to them, they'll make
the decision with you, then you own it.

113
00:05:33.510 --> 00:05:37.750
Rarely did we do a level three team, but
when we did, I did do what the team wanted

114
00:05:37.750 --> 00:05:41.120
to do, and I took full responsibility and
accountability for the outcome.

115
00:05:41.120 --> 00:05:44.340
And very, very, very rarely did I
make a level four decision, but

116
00:05:44.340 --> 00:05:47.110
when I did,
my entire team got right behind me.

117
00:05:47.110 --> 00:05:50.980
>> It sounds like a culture thing as well
that you've gotta kind of instill that

00:05:50.980 --> 00:05:53.990
culture at the beginning within your
team and also within the company.

00:05:53.990 --> 00:05:58.113
I'm thinking back to that 82%, that the
reason those people are probably feeling

00:05:58.113 --> 00:06:01.605
the way they are is because they're
worried if my boss sees that I've got

00:06:01.605 --> 00:06:04.255

122
00:06:04.255 --> 00:06:09.240
That maybe they'll give them my job, so
having that culture where delegation and

123
00:06:09.240 --> 00:06:13.830
empowering your employees to really
make those decisions on their own.

124
00:06:13.830 --> 00:06:16.540
That's a great thing in a company culture,
I think.

125
00:06:16.540 --> 00:06:20.990
>> Well, it's essential to running a great
business that can be agile and quick and

126
00:06:20.990 --> 00:06:22.700
adaptable in a market place.

127
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:26.540
Where decisions are made correctly and
quickly, and that people feel like they

128
00:06:26.540 --> 00:06:29.780
have a say in the outcome,
that gives them a stake in the outcome.

129
00:06:29.780 --> 00:06:31.280
And all those things are great.

00:06:31.280 --> 00:06:33.200
There's the other side of it though,

131
00:06:33.200 --> 00:06:37.260

00:06:37.260 --> 00:06:42.830

00:06:42.830 --> 00:06:45.930

00:06:45.930 --> 00:06:49.910

00:06:49.910 --> 00:06:52.050

00:06:52.050 --> 00:06:54.770

00:06:54.770 --> 00:06:56.504
Or if you've got a small

00:06:56.504 --> 00:07:01.620

a way to deal with employees

00:07:01.620 --> 00:07:05.310

do, who aren't meeting the standards.

00:07:19.980 --> 00:07:22.770

00:07:22.770 --> 00:07:25.830

148
00:07:25.830 --> 00:07:28.670

00:07:36.270 --> 00:07:37.300

00:07:43.310 --> 00:07:46.850

00:07:46.850 --> 00:07:49.460

00:07:49.460 --> 00:07:52.840

00:08:00.670 --> 00:08:04.930
As clearly as possible what you're

00:08:04.930 --> 00:08:07.130

00:08:07.130 --> 00:08:08.030

00:08:08.030 --> 00:08:08.730

00:08:08.730 --> 00:08:09.920

00:08:11.390 --> 00:08:15.640

166
00:08:15.640 --> 00:08:19.830

00:08:19.830 --> 00:08:21.520

Most of the companies I've owned or

00:08:30.070 --> 00:08:33.120

00:08:33.120 --> 00:08:36.340

I'm gonna give you everything
